What guarantees can the minister give to Australians taxpayers that the Energy Credit Scheme will not see a blow-out in costs?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âLet me make it absolutely clear to you that there is one thing which is a major difference between the coalition and the Labor Party, and that is that we are wanting to deliver cheaper diesel fuel costs to the public. Your policy, Senator, is to have high diesel prices; our policy is to have lower diesel prices. I can absolutely assure that you that our policy is one which will be widely welcomed by the public, as distinct from the Labor Party policy on diesel fuel. You can be absolutely assured that the diesel credit scheme, along with all other schemes administered by this government, will be administered at world's best practice. Let me make it absolutely clear that we make no apology for delivering cheaper fuel prices to rural and regional Australia. This is one of the many big pluses in this package.
âHow much will it cost?
âOrder! Senator Murphy, you will have the opportunity to ask a supplementary question. Shouting out further questions while the minister is answering is not appropriate.

âI make this point to the Labor Party: we believe that when we go out to rural and regional Australia our cheaper fuel policies will be very much welcomed. I assure you that the Labor Party policy of higher fuel prices will be totally rejected by the electorate.
âI have a question for Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Justice and Customs. What action is the government taking to combat the growing global problem of illegal immigration?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: âI thank the senator for his question. Coming from Western Australia he no doubt has a very close interest in this matter. People smuggling is a growing problem worldwide. Countries such as Australia, the United States and Canada have all seen very substantial increases in the number of people attempting to enter illegally. Globally, the number is estimated to be around four million attempts each year. In addition to the problem growing, the nature of the problem is changing. It is now a sophisticated, organised criminal business worth at least $10 billion. In addition to the old wooden fishing vessels, we now have large steel-hulled vessels with sophisticated radar, global positioning equipment and hidden compartments. These new challenges require a systematic and considered response. Yesterday's announcement by the Prime Minister was just that.

answer.para: The Australian government will spend an additional $124 million over four years to strengthen our capacity to detect and deter illegal arrivals. The initiatives include two additional Dash 8 aircraft to extend the footprint and intensity of Coastwatch's aerial surveillance, especially along eastern Australia, the apparent new favoured target; an additional night capable helicopter to be deployed in the Torres Strait; the establishment of a national surveillance centre at Coastwatch's Canberra headquarters, with electronic links to state government agencies and defence establishments; the creation of a new position, Director-General of Coastwatch, which will be filled by a senior officer of the Australian Defence Force. Liaison arrangements between Coastwatch, Defence and other agencies will also be strengthened. Twelve immigration officers will be posted overseas to major source and transit countries, including airport liaison officers at key airports. Bilateral agreements with source and transit countries will be concluded for cooperation on people smuggling issues and to provide for the return of illegal arrivals.

Australia will also give very strong support for the conclusion, as soon as possible, of a protocol on people smuggling in the proposed United Nations Convention on Transnational Organised Crime. A high level committee chaired by the Office of National Assessments will also be established to coordinate information and intelligence on people smuggling. People smuggling, as with other crimes, is best targeted with intelligence at hand to focus one's resources appropriately. We will also introduce comprehensive legislative amendments to strengthen maritime investigatory and enforcement powers, and those provisions will be complemented by legislation that will strengthen penalties against people smuggling. There will be an opportunity soon for Labor and the Democrats to support increased penalties in relation to this area.

The government has therefore taken a very comprehensive and holistic approach. We are doing this by making sure that the key agencies involved can respond to the changing nature of people smuggling by having better intelligence, better coordination and far more resources.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Despite the $124 million funding boost and the positive reception by both the media and general public, is the minister aware of any negative comments about these initiatives?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: âAs it happens, yes, I am. Mr Sciacca has said that massive cuts to expenditure over recent years by the government have resulted in reductions in staffing. Mr Kerr claims that the new funding is largely a robbing Peter to pay Paul exercise and that we are simply repackaging funding slashed in previous years. They both could not be more wrong. It is about time somebody took them to task for us. I look forward to the media taking up this issue. The expenditure in 1994-95 was $24.5 million.
âIt is always politicisedâevery time.

âI acknowledge Senator Ray saying that I always politicise it. It was not us, Madam President, who put out the misinformation criticising this additional funding for Coastwatch. If Labor are happy to politicise it, we are happy to meet them head-on with that. We have shifted the funding from $24.5 million to an estimated expenditure this year of $35.7 million. The area covered in square nautical miles has increased dramatically from 29 million to an expected 84 million this year. (Time expired) .

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Rural and Regional Australia

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Ian Macdonald, the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. Has the minister seen the analysis of the publication Inside Canberra that the excise savings on diesel which will result from the GST packageâafter all the government's hype on the bonanza for the bushâwill mean a saving of only 0.33 cents in the dollar on food costs in rural and regional Australia? What does the government's own modelling of the impact of the GST package on food prices in country Australia show? Does it confirm the analysis by Inside Canberra ?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Mackay for the question because I do not often get a question from Senator Mackay. I am grateful whenever one comes. Unfortunately, Senator Mackay, I am not at my sparkling best today, so you will have to persevere.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThank you for your sympathy. I appreciate that. I understand that the publication Senator Mackay referred to is a Labor Party publication. It is written by a fellow traveller, or someone. So I cannot confess to having read the article that the senator referred to. What I can say is that any reduction in fuel prices will be of particular benefit to those of us who live in rural and regional Australia. You, Senator Mackay, living in a state that is remote from the mainland capitals, would also appreciate that the costs of transport have an enormous impact on every aspect of life in rural and regional Australia. I am sure they do in Tasmania, notwithstanding that the Howard government has done a lot to help Tasmania with its freight equalisation scheme and passenger vehicle subsidy scheme.

answer.para: We have done a lot to help Tasmania and we want to help all parts of rural and regional Australia. The best way we can do that is by reducing the costs of transport. I do not have the figures that Senator Mackay referred to. I suspect they would be open to challenge. It simply stands to reason that, if you reduce the costs of transport both on road and rail, you will get cheaper transport costs out into the regions and that will mean cheaper goods for all.

talk.start.para: âIf only the reductions are passed onâand only then.
âOrder! Conversations across the chamber are disorderly.
âSenator Cook, you are suggesting that the reductions are not going to be passed on.
âSome of them.
âYou are suggesting that the transport companies are going to put the money straight into their pocket. Is that what you are suggesting?
âYep.
âI hope that your mates in the Transport Workers Union understand your saying that because they, likeâ

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYou don't have any mates in the Transport Workers Union? I am not surprised. I would be surprised if you had mates anywhere. Senator Cook, you have lost Senator Conroy.

answer.para: I am interested to take this up because in the consultations that we have hadâand I do not mean particularly formal consultations; I mean going round to transport companies in rural and regional Australia and discussing this with them, as we on this side have done and you obviously have not doneâthey have said to us that the transport industry is so competitive that if they do not reduce their costs they will go out of business. One transport company will reduce its costs and, if the others do not do so, they will go out of business. Senator Cook shakes his head, but that confirms that he has no idea and he has not consulted with the transport industry or the Transport Workers Union. I suggest that he does those sorts of things. It is a fairly simple proposition: once you reduce the costs of transportâtransport has a big impact on those of us living in rural and regional Australiaâyou must get cheaper goods and services.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I presume the minister has taken the first part of my question on notice. Perhaps he could clarify that when he answers my supplementary question. Is the minister aware that the same analysis shows that the GST package will actually widen the disparity in petrol prices between the city and the bush by bringing about a small reduction in city prices, of about 0.7c per litre on a price of 70c a litre, and an increase in prices in any country areas where petrol is sold at 80c a litre or more? Does the minister agree that the package will exacerbate the current disadvantage of country Australia with respect to city petrol prices? If not, what is the minister's own analysis of the impact of the package on the city-country petrol price disparity?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âI am not sure that I got all of the question, and I apologise for that.
âTell your colleagues to shut up while you are being asked a question.
âThank you, Senator Conroy. It would be useful also if you would shut up, as you say.
âYou would not be so polite.

âThat is his comment; not mine. I would not use that sort of language. I am quoting Senator Conroy. The disparity in fuel prices between city and regional areas is what I understood to be the import of Senator Mackay's question. The point I try to get over to Senator Mackay all the time is that petrol prices are going the right way under our government. Under 13 years of Labor all that happened with petrol prices out in the bush was that they went up. Services left the bush and petrol prices went up. In fact, the price of most things in the bush went up during Labor's 13 long years. We are addressing that now. (Time expired)

âMy question is addressed to the minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator Alston. I ask the minister: does the minister agree that any further deregulation of the dairy industry will cause harm to Australian dairy farmers? Does the minister agree with National Party Senator Ron Boswell's statement last year that deregulation of the dairy industry would only benefit the big supermarket chains? Will the government therefore reconsider its push to deregulate one of our most profitable rural industries? I acknowledge Senator Boswell: he is right.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI do not think that the government is in the business of wanting to damage the dairy industry. By the same token, we are certainly very committed to ensuring that the benefits of deregulation are fully appreciated. ABARE released its analysis of the potential impacts of deregulation on Australia's dairy farmers at Outlook `99 earlier this year and this analysis was based on its assumptions regarding the farm gate price of milk in a deregulated market. The government's understanding is that the analysis does not fully take account of the substantial commercial benefits that industry sees coming from deregulation. At the time the ABARE estimates were released, dairy industry leaders queried the ABARE assumptions, arguing that the impact of deregulation would be much less severe than ABARE estimates. Indeed, the Australian Dairy Industry Council, the peak industry organisation, claims that the current price premium on market milk will not decline by as much as ABARE assumes. They argue that dairy processors and manufacturers will still need to offer incentives to secure a continuous supply of milk throughout the year.

answer.para: I think it is fair to say that Senator Boswell is always out there ensuring that the best interests of people in rural areas are properly protected and I am sure that he will be an active participant in the debate. But I am sure that the last thing that he would want would be to prematurely close down a sensible discussion of how we might actually be able to achieve some lasting benefits from a sensible approach to deregulation

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer and he is right about Senator Boswell. In part of your answer to the question, you said that commercial benefits would flow from deregulation. My question is: to whom, given thatâand I wonder if you are aware of thisâafter partial deregulation of the dairy industry this year, rises have not flowed back to dairy farmers but have simply improved profits for the big supermarkets?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThere seems to be a bit of misunderstanding on the part of Senator Woodley that one should always simply assess the benefits in terms of the suppliers, but I think it is a very important thing to take into account that essentially competition and deregulation are aimed at benefiting consumers. Therefore, I think you have to take a global view of the issue and not simply look at what impact, in the short term, one particular change might have made. At the end of the day, if you end up with a more efficient industry, lower prices and a better quality of milk, you have had a win all round.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Comments by Victorian Premier

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Did the Assistant Treasurer see the following comments of the Victorian Premier, Jeff Kennett:

question.para: It is not Howard's package but the Democrats package and I tragically fear we are going to pay a very high price.
. . . the benefits are going . . . to be questionable.
. . . because this is going to be such a complicated piece of legislation . . . governments now . . . will alter the taxation system in part every year.

No doubt the Assistant Treasurer will totally disagree with Mr Kennett and claim that he has got it completely wrong. But what are Australians to make of it when one of the Liberal Party's most successful national figures makes claims about your crowning glory, the GST, which are diametrically opposed to the claims made by your own government?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âSenator, I would have thought that you would have been more worried about the comments in the battle between Mr Della Bosca and Gary Gray at present andâ
âSenator, you should direct your remarks to the Chair.

âthe serious questions which are being posed over the leadership of Mr Beazley because what we are seeing in the Labor Party is a total policy vacuum. When these bills are finally through the Senate, the absolute nakedness of the Labor Party in relation to policy will be totally exposed. The fact is that we have had 65 hours of debate and there has been no significant contribution by the Labor Party; there has been massive time wasting; and the Labor Party has put forward no alternative, with the sole exception of continuing with a completely outdated, complex wholesale sales tax system which only five other countries in the world, including Botswana, are prepared to accept. Nobody wants to adopt your system.
âSenator Kemp, I do draw your attention to the question that was asked.

âThank you, Madam President. I have seen comments by Mr Kennett in relation to the package and I do not agree with those comments. There are huge benefits for Australians out of this system. Look at the enormous costs which will come off business and the huge savings which we will make in the export sector as a result of this package. Mr Kennett could not have been thinking, when he made those comments, of the huge benefits of the $12 billion tax cuts going to families.

answer.para: This is the largest tax cut in Australian history, a huge tax cut which the Labor Party opposes. I do not think Mr Kennett could have been thinking about the real rise in pensions which is going to occur as a result of this packageâof the real benefits flowing to the people on pensions and benefits. There are huge benefits under this package. It is quite clear that, in order to get the package through the Senate, the government had to enter into constructive negotiations with other parties. The Labor Party was not interested in tax reform. It went missing in action.

As is well known, we held very constructive talks with the Democrats and we believe we have a package now before the Senate which amounts to real tax reform. It is a package which will deliver huge benefits to business, huge benefits to families and huge benefits to rural and regional Australia. The fact is that the Labor Party does not have a single solitary idea on what to do about tax reform. Senator, you have been the laziest opposition that we have ever seen.

talk.start.para: âSenator, you should direct your remarks to the chair.

âThere has not been a sensible or constructive idea. Madam President, the Labor Party are totally exposed for their failure to take part in any constructive negotiations on tax reform, unlike the Australian Democrats.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question, taking the minister back to the question rather than the Labor Party. Does the Assistant Treasurer deny that Australians will pay a high price for the hybrid GST, that its benefits are questionable and that the package is so complicated it will have to be altered every year? Is he absolutely right while Mr Kennett is absolutely wrong?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âMadam President, this is always the problem when someone has a supplementary question written out and they refuse to listen to the answer. I have been through that. Mr Kennett, in relation to those comments, is wrongâI have said that. I have been through, in quite exquisite detail, the benefits which will flow to the Australian public as a result of this package. Senator, you should listen to the answers rather than just tritely read out a supplementary question which has already been written down.

âOrder! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of the Speaker of the parliament of Singapore, Mr Tan Soo Khoon. On behalf of honourable senators I have pleasure in welcoming you to the chamber and trust that your visit to this country will be enjoyable and informative. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite the Speaker to take a seat on the floor of the chamber.
âHear, hear!

âMadam President, my question is to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Minchin. I refer to an article in today's Age which points out that, under new federal government policy, farmers will be allowed to grow genetically modified crops that are toxic to birds, insects and grazing animals and which could make some weeds resistant to herbicides. Last week the European Union announced a moratorium on the release of such crops. Given the rapidly rising concern in Australia about this issue, is this not exactly the kind of issue for which the environment minister should take full responsibility? Is it a fact that, under the old environment laws, the Commonwealth had the power to require an environmental impact assessment for imports of such organisms and that, once the office of gene regulator was established, the Commonwealth would have had the power to require an EIS for the release of such organisms? Why, then, did the Democrats and government guillotine new environmental laws through the Senate last week which would prevent the Commonwealth from requiring an EIS on GMOs? (Time expired)

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: âI am advised that, under the new legislation, the regulation of genetically modified organisms with regard to the environment will in fact be an improvement. The government will, in conjunction with the establishment of the new gene technology regulatorâthat is, the Gene Technology Officeâintroduce amendments to the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act to ensure that decisions of this new gene technology regulator in relation to environmentally significant releases of genetically modified organisms and products are subject to environmental assessment.

answer.para: The Department of Health and Aged Care is currently preparing legislation to establish this new office of the gene technology regulator and will, following that drafting, consult with all stakeholders, including environment groups and state governments, and introduce that legislation into parliament. The situation will be an improvement. Under the old EPIP Act there had been absolutely no referrals to the environment minister of GMO decisions, so we do believe this will be an improvement.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the honour able minister: what is a `significant' organism? What does the word `significant' mean in relation to genetically modified organisms? Does this not open the avenue for a complete cop-out by the Commonwealth? Secondly, I repeat the question: why did not the government and the Democrats ensure that a trigger mechanism was available to ensure full Commonwealth assessment of the impact of genetically modified organisms before their release in Australia before guillotining this legislation through last week?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: âIt is not a cop-out, it is an improvement. We have taken the necessary steps to ensure, as I have said, that environmentally significant releases of genetically modified organisms are subject to environmental assessment. That will be a matter for debate. The legislation will be presented and you can debate the question of the definition of `environmentally significant'. But it is an improvement and a much better deal for the environment.

âMadam President, my question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Alston. How does the minister respond to the report on private sector executive salaries in the Weekend Australian , which cited 19 senior executives who each receive an average annual salary of $2.6 million? Does the government believe that it is fair and acceptable that 19 senior executives receive almost $50 million between them? If not, what concrete steps is the government taking to curb such gross excesses?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âMadam President, that is a classic example of the politics of envy because quite clearly Senator Denman is saying that, simply because someone gets a particular level of salary that is not available to the vast majority of other Australians, by definition that person could not be entitled to it.
âShe's actually asking you a question.

âShe did, she asked me whether 19 people getting $2.6 millionâa total of $50 millionâis somehow outrageous and obscene. I am in the process of explaining why it is not. What I think might be a much more constructive approach to take, Madam President, would be to look at whether or not people ought to be entitled to significant pay increases when they are in charge of companies that have a bad year. I think you are on much stronger ground if you do that because then you are looking at performance. I understand why you blokes are not interested in performanceâit is because none of you would be here if you were paid on merit.

âMadam President, I raise a point of order. Did you note, Madam President, that Senator Alston is not addressing you, not addressing the Senate through the chair, and is talking about `you blokes'? I assume he is also referring to Senator Denman as `you'. When other senators do it you rule them out of order. I wonder if you would do that on this occasion and ask him to address his comments through the chair.
âI think both senators at the table have been in breach of the standing orders: you for interjecting during the answer to the question and the minister for not addressing his remarks to the chair.

âThankyou, Madam President, for that timely reminder. The fact is that there are a number of people in the Australian work force who are entitled to very generous pay packages measured by the standards of, say, AWE or those who might earn a lot less than AWE. At the end of the day you have to look at what they are being paid to do.
âYou see, he is doing it again.
âI am not talking about you personally, Madam President. Senator Faulkner does not understand. I suppose he thinks the plural of you is youse. I was using it in the plural.
âWhere did you learn that? Brighton Grammar?
âI doubt that you would know the difference.
âOrder! Senator Denman wants an answer to her question and her own senators should cease interjecting.

âThe proper approach to take is to look at whether the particular salary is appropriate to the level of responsibility. A number of our leading Australian companies are indeed major players, both domestically and internationally. The sorts of salary levels that are paid here are often well below those available in the international marketplace. I know you do not believe in any of those things.
âYou are doing it again.

âI thought I explained to you that `you' is plural as well as singular. Madam President, if Senator Faulkner does not want to listen I am afraid I cannot help that. I make the point that by some standards the levels of executive remuneration in this country are generous, by other standards they are probably less than available on world market places. At the end of the day you are on much safer ground to look at whether the position attracts a commensurate salary and then start to debate the merits.

answer.para: Those opposite think we ought to somehow draw a line and say, `No-one should be entitled to a salary in excess of,' what, `a million'? I presume the left wing of the Labor Party would think a million is pretty obscene. Half a million? They would probably think that was pretty outrageous too. Madam President, you simply cannot get into that business. Look at things on their merits and you will make a lot more progress.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Environmental Impact

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Minchin. Has the government performed any analysis of the environmental impact of the revised tax package and will the minister inform the Senate of what the impact on air quality and greenhouse emissions will be?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: âThere have been a lot of false claims made about the environmental impact of the government's new tax package. Regrettably, a lot of that seems to be based on the work of Dr Clive Hamilton of the Australia Institute. The government now has some new analysis done by Environment Australia and the Australian Greenhouse Office, drawing on work done by the Bureau of Transport Economics and ABARE. The research shows that Dr Hamilton's assumptions about the impact of the new tax system are wrong. Dr Hamilton has overstated the greenhouse implications of the original tax package and ignored the greenhouse savings impacts of the renewable energy and transport initiatives in the revised package. He also fails to take into account the additional greenhouse savings to be generated by the $100 million a year greenhouse abatement program that will run for four years.

answer.para: The new work confirms the positive environmental outcomes secured during the negotiations with the Democratsâdelivering benefits both in terms of air quality and greenhouse gas savings. This new analysis shows the revised tax package will deliver greenhouse gas savings of 5.5 megatonnes by 2010 compared with business as usual. It is significant that the analysis used to obtain this figure was put out for independent review by respected energy economist Dr David James. He has indicated that the estimated greenhouse emission savings almost certainly will be significantly greater than those stated. In simple terms, the deal secured with the Democrats will ensure that there is no detrimental impact on greenhouse gas emissions as a result of tax reform. In fact, there will be a net benefit in terms of greenhouse savings.

The news is just as good on air quality. The Bureau of Transport Economics estimates the revised tax package delivers a reduction of 40 per cent on business as usual projections for particle emissions from the transport sector by 2015. In fact, particle emission levels from the transport sector in 2015 are predicted to be below 1997 levels. This is because the package negotiated with the Democrats will deliver cleaner fuel and better engine technology.

So it is clear that the changes negotiated do deliver significant environmental benefits for air quality and greenhouse gas savings. It will give the Senate even greater confidence that there will be no detrimental impact on the environment from the revised tax package. I am pleased to table the new research, the advice of Dr David James, and a brief covering note from the minister.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Alston, the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Can the Minister confirm that, after an earlier episode of conflict of interests, the Secretary to Prime Minister and Cabinet was required by the Prime Minister to cross-check the public and confidential statements of interests for all frontbenchers and to have any anomalies corrected? Did Mr Moore-Wilton scrutinise the interest declarations for the Parliamentary Secretary to Cabinet? Did he raise the absence of Sestial Pty Ltd from the Senate register with the Prime Minister or Senator Heffernan? Under this cross-checking system, how is it that Senator Heffernan disclosed his directorship and shareholding in Sestial to the Prime Minister in October last year but waited three months to declare his directorship to the Senate and chose not to disclose his beneficial shareholding at all? What does Mr Moore-Wilton actually do?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âHe does a great deal more than anyone on the other side of the chamber does. He does it very effectively. As head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet he has very onerous responsibilities and he carries them out very well.

answer.para: I am not prepared to guttercrawl on this issue. I know the strategy; you really are not interested in the answer. You just want to put the question on notice, under privilege and hope that somehow it will get a run. If you are serious about these sorts of issues, Senator Quirke, through you Madam President, then you will urge Senator Faulkner to go outside this chamber and apologise to the Baillieu family, which he has consistently refused to do now for some years. Mr Maurice Baillieu died only 38 years ago and Mr Richard Baillieu died 58 years ago, but, having seriously defamed them under parliamentary privilege, Senator Faulkner is not prepared to go that little bit further and put out a press release to give the Baillieu family an opportunity to clear the record.

talk.start.para: âSenator Alston, I draw your attention to the question.
âUntil that is done, Madam President, Labor simply cannot be taken seriously on this issue.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister explain why Mr Max Moore-Wilton has failed to perform even the most elementary cross-check of frontbenchers' declarations with the latest available data from the Australian Securities and Investment Commission? Is the abject failure of both the Prime Minister and his senior bureaucrat to check the veracity and accuracy of ministerial declarations of interest due to their incompetence or their contempt for the parliamentary disclosure system?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI am not prepared to make any assumptions that are built into that question. I simply proceed on the basis that Mr Moore-Wilton and the Prime Minister undertook their duties conscientiously. I just wish those on the other side would do the same.

âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. What involvement has the federal government had in negotiations regarding the development of the south-east Queensland regional forest agreement? Is the minister aware that the south-east Queensland region contains the second greatest degree of biodiversity in Australia? What is the minister's response to statements made by Queensland environment organisations that the current proposals for the south-east Queensland RFA put south-east Queensland's forests at serious risk? Will the minister guarantee that the federal government will not sign off on any agreement unless it clearly meets the JANIS criteria and enjoys the protection of the biodiversity of south-east Queensland's native forests?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: âIn response to that question from Senator Bartlett, I advise that the Commonwealth is committed to achieving a balanced regional forest agreement outcome in south-east Queensland. The government does recognise the diverse range of regional ecosystems and other conservation values that do require protection, but at the same time we are also conscious that regional communities and businesses rely heavily on a stable and sustainable timber industry for viability. We are exploring, through Minister Tuckey, all opportunities to develop a progressive and internationally competitive regional timber industry consistent with the environmental values we seek to protect.

answer.para: In relation to the development of this RFA in south-east Queensland, the directions report was released on 14 May for about six weeks of public comment. It presents indicative scenarios illustrating key RFA negotiation issues. Other recently released RFA reports on the south-east Queensland region include the comprehensive regional assessment of the region's forests environmental, social, economic and cultural values, and the social assessment report, which consolidates social analysis and information obtained in the comprehensive regional assessment and which is specifically designed to provide stakeholders, communities and governments with a clear understanding of the implications of forest management decisions on communities. The Commonwealth still intends to finalise the south-east Queensland regional forest agreement in the second half of 1999, in cooperation with the Queensland government.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister outline to the Senate in what ways the options outlined in the directions paper actually meet adequate fauna habitat protection standards? The RFA is supposed to provide a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system for forest protection. Will the government make available statistics on species and habitat, as well as regional ecosystems and alternative employment options, to ensure that the community can assess adequately and accurately that the requirement for adequate protection of the south-east Queensland forests is met?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: âI hope that Senator Bartlett would understand that I will need to take that question on notice and get him an answer as soon as I can.

âMy question is to Senator Vanstone, representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. The minister would be aware of her government's commitment to the removal of cabotage, thereby allowing foreign ships unrestricted access to the Australian coast. Is the minister aware that her former colleague the then minister for transport, Mr Sharp, received a report in March 1997, prepared by Mr Julian Manser, that warned that the removal of cabotage would require substantial changes to Australian immigration and customs controls. Is the minister aware that the current Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Mr Anderson, has recently received another report on shipping reform? Can the minister confirm that this second report also addresses the issue of cabotage and immigration and customs control? Would the end of cabotage require changes to allow foreign seafarers to work in Australia for extended periods of time? Can the minister assure the Senate that the liberalised customs and immigration arrangements necessitated by the end of cabotage would not result in an increased number of people attempting to enter Australia illegally?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: âI thank the senator for his question. The answer to the first question is no; to the second is no; to the third is no; to the fourth, I am unable to say; and to the fifth, I will make inquiries and get back to you.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the minister is not aware of either the first report or the report currently before the minister, will the minister undertake to make inquiries and to respond to the Senate in relation to that part of the question which arises from those reports, essentially the question of whether the end of cabotage would require changes to allow foreign seafarers to work in Australia for extended periods of time and whether that would then necessitate changes to arrangements so that it would not result in an increased number of people attempting to enter Australia illegally?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: âYour supplementary was basically a repeat of your fifth question, and in response to that I said that I will make inquiries and get back to you. I repeat the answer.

âMy question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island Affairs, Senator Herron. Will the minister outline the very important progress that he is making in reducing family violence in indigenous communities?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Ferris for her question and for her continued interest in this problem. I am pleased to inform the Senate that ATSIC has agreed to fund $1 million in programs for indigenous women, men, their families and communities experiencing family violence. I welcome ATSIC's cooperation in accepting that family violence is an issue that must be a priority in the ATSIC budget. I have been arguing for some time that ATSIC should put resources into family violence, and ATSIC has agreed to fund the $1 million program in the next financial year by taking $500,000 from its $11 million travel budget and another $500,000 from its $13 million public information expenditure.

answer.para: Family violence is a serious and distressing issue and I am pleased that key players like ATSIC and some states and territories recognise that we cannot ignore the problem. While family violence is primarily a state and territory responsibility, the Commonwealth does have a role to play. Shortly, I will host a second roundtable conference on family violence in Brisbane. It will involve community people who have on the ground experience in this difficult area and, in particular, it will involve men. I am convinced that there must be community ownership if we are to successfully tackle this problem.

Almost invariably, men are the perpetrators and women are the victims, and the idea of the roundtable is to look at practical solutions and to take forward ideas to the peak Ministerial Council of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs ministers meeting in the Northern Territory in September. At that MCATSIA meeting, I will ask the states and territories to play a greater role in addressing the problem of family violence. I believe it is important to be able to say that the Commonwealth, through ATSIC and through mainstream programs, is willing to play its part.

I have been talking about family violence for some time now but, until recently, very few people have been listening. Issues like deaths in custody seem to get a lot of attention, but the fact is that, since 1990, 30 per cent more indigenous Australians died as a result of family violence than died in custody. There were 163 family violence deathsâmainly of womenâversus 126 deaths in custody. The federal government is taking a leading role in attempting to prevent family violence. Under the Prime Minister's strong leadership, we have committed $50 million over the past two budgets to the Partnerships Against Domestic Violence Program, which is focusing on the key areas of indigenous family violence, children at risk as witnesses, work with perpetrators and community education. I would also like to congratulate the Cape York Health Council on its new initiative to assist indigenous women and children experiencing family violence. This $550,000 family violence advocacy project is funded under the Partnerships Against Domestic Violence Program, and it will make a significant contribution to better outcomes for indigenous women and children.

The Commonwealth is also providing accommodation assistance for women and children escaping family violence under the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program. I have also asked them to look at the fact that we take the women and children out of their homes and give them protection, when in fact we should be taking the perpetrators out of the home and putting them in sobering-up centres or somewhere so the women and children can stay in their homes. The Commonwealth is providing an extra $45 million over three years to the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program as a result of the new tax package. That is on top of the $45 million announced in last month's federal budget. The Commonwealth is committed to helping create stronger families and stronger communities through stopping family violence.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Local Government

talk.start.para: âI have another question to Senator Macdonald, the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. Is the minister aware of a KPMG report commissioned by the Local Government Association of Queensland which shows initial GST compliance costs of up to $200,000, ongoing compliance costs of up to $15,000, plus a cash flow effect of up to $400,000 for councils in Queensland? Is he aware of the independent study carried out by the Municipal Association of Victoria which estimates that compliance costs for some Victorian councils could be up to $1 million per council and some $200,000 per year thereafter? How does this square with the minister's statement that compliance costs for local government will be minimal?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âI was aware of the MAVâMunicipal Association of Victoriaâreport. I recall that Senator Mackay issued a press release off the back of that saying `$1 million compliance costs for all councils' or something like thatâsomething completely over the top and outrageous. It was a report that lacked any intellectual expertise.
âWhat about the LGAQ one?

âI will come to the LGAQ one, but I just want to finish on the MAV one. Unfortunately, the MAV were working off the sorts of stories that you and your colleagues were putting around, so they were working on the wrong premise. They had their facts and information wrong. I do not mind saying this about them because I sat with them at one of their council meetings and told them that to their face. I explained to them where they were wrong. They had the basic facts incorrect. When I explained that to them they said, `Oh, that does make a difference, doesn't it. That does make a difference.'
âHow?

âI could tell the senator the answer to this chapter and verse. This was a question that I was prepared for about four months ago whenâit didn't really hit the press too muchâSenator Mackay issued her press release. It was wrong in its basic understanding of the facts. From memory, I think one of the things was that they had local government putting in a return every three months. That was completely wrong. Local government can put it in in one month and that makes an enormous difference to their cash flow and to the whole import. There were many examples like that where they were simply wrong in fact so, obviously, they got it wrong in their assessment.

answer.para: I did not quite hear what you said in the question, but I understand from your interjection that it was about the LGAQ report.

talk.start.para: âThe KPMG report.

âThe KPMG report done by local governmentâand that was a better assessment. As KPMG said, a lot of it was still uncertain. They were not quite sure how it would impact. I think they had four or five councils who did the work and KPMG worked with them. They had a range of figures on what it would cost local councils. I think they ranged from around $6,000 for a small rural council, up to about $150,000. Do not hold me to that, SenatorâI am just going from memory. As I say, when this first came out I had all the details, but my memory is a little hazy after so many months. Certainly, it was in that range.

answer.para: I have said to local government that, as the legislation is passed and as we know exactly what the situation is and what the system will be for local government, then I would sit down with themâI would get Treasury and the National Office of Local Government to sit down with the LGAQ and any of the other state associationsâand their consultants and go through it to see whether they are correct or not. I have always said to local government that we understand that there will be some impact. We do not want councils to bear the full burden of that. There have been a number of measures announced that will help councils through this period. The tax office will set up a unit that will go around and explain things to them. As the senator will be aware, the local government incentive program, a new programâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister may have been prepared for the answer four months ago but, of course, he refused to answer any questions at all in relation to the GST and local government during estimates. If the minister accepts that the LGAQ-KPMG report is in fact a fair assessment, isn't it true that the government's local government incentive program, which will primarily assist councils with GST compliance costs and provide $7 million over two years to 710 councils, will result in less than $10,000 per council? The minister surely would not be surprised to learn that local government regards this program as simply a joke.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âNone of the local government bodies that I have spoken to have thought the local government incentive program was a joke. In fact, they are very much looking forward to its implementation. They understand that there will be costs involved and that the government will go out of its way to assist local government through the implementation period. Senator Mackay mentions that I would not answer questions in estimates. I am glad she did that because, as I said to her then, this was the place to answer those questions. It is an issue that does not come into effect until next year's budget and the Senate estimates committees are of course for the budget 1999-2000. That is why I would not answer them, not because I did not want to. I am very happy to answer them all the time at any time. I am very happy to answer them.
âNo-one can pass you notes in estimates.
âWell, if someone is passing me notes, they should do it in a way that I can read what they are saying.

âMy question is for the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Would the minister advise the Senate of the Howard government's action to deliver quality training to ensure our continuing success within the global community?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: âCan I acknowledge Senator Synon's longstanding interest in vocational education and training, and it is experience we will sorely miss after her departure this Wednesday from the Senate. It might interest Senator Carr to know that at the recent ANTA ministerial council there was an affirmation by all state and territory governments with the Commonwealth to pursue quality training. In fact, there was an acknowledgment that training in this country was going in the right direction, and that is in stark contrast to what Senator Carr said in relation to the training system vis-a-vis the Commonwealth and especially the Queensland government.

answer.para: There have been great reforms in relation to training in this country. In fact, we have seen recently the introduction of new apprenticeships. You may ask why they are called `new apprenticeships'. They are new because they are introducing new industrial sectors to the concept of training. They are involving industry training criteria so that industry is becoming involved in the training itself. We are also looking at expanding them into regional Australia. We are looking at increasing apprenticeships in regional Australia by some 30,000 places.

talk.start.para: âWhat are you doing about the rorting?
âSenator Carr, stop shouting.

âThose are some 30,000 places, Senator Carr. Madam President, Senator Carr also needs to bear in mind the recent budget where we committed $130 million over four years, bringing total funding to $1.6 billion for that sector. Madam President, you are seeing reforms in this country which have never been seen before, and you have seen a commitment from this federal government to the training sector which has not been seen before. This has been acknowledged by state and territory governments and we look forward to working with those governments to pursue excellence in training.
âMadam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âLast Thursday Senator Chris Evans asked me a question and I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as followsâ

SENATOR CHRIS EVANS âMy question is directed to Senator Herron, in his capacity representing the Minister for Aged Care. Is the minister aware that, on 1 July, aged care residents in Tasmania and Victoria will not receive full indexation to their care subsidies? Can the minister confirm that this real cut in aged care funding in Victoria and Tasmania flows from the government's policy of coalescence? Why is the government continuing with this policy when the Productivity Commission inquiry that the government initiated recommended against it proceeding, finding that it would leave the quality of care as the balancing item in the funding arrangements? Why has the government refused to respond to the Productivity Commission's report, handed to the Treasurer on 13 January this year? Will the minister now give an assurance that the 21,000 residents of nursing homes in Tasmania and Victoria will not have their care subsidies cut in real terms from 1 July?

SENATOR CHRIS EVANS âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Contrary to the gratuitous abuse the minister provided in answer to the question, this is a very real issue. The Productivity Commission reported to the government on 13 January and recommended that they drop the coalescence proposal. It was an inquiry that the government initiated and that raised serious concerns in the community. What I want to know, Minister, and I appreciate you will take it on notice and give a proper answer, is why you have not responded to that report and why the government has not done anything to address the Productivity Commission's concern that the standard of care in Victoria and Tasmania will drop under your proposal. 1 July is next week, and we still not do not know what you are going to do and whether or not you intend responding. I think it is important that the Senate and the community get an answer.

Senator HERRON âTasmanian and Victorian providers will receive a real increase in funding on 1 July. In Tasmania, providers will receive a real increase in funding in 1999-2000 of $5.1 million, or 5.1%, over that provided in 1998-99 Victorian providers will receive a real increase in funding of $36.6 million which is a 4.5% increase
The Government will provide $3.5 billion for residential care in the next financial yearâan increase of more than $200 million over 1998-99, which includes $48.9 million for indexation.

The additional funds to residential aged care services will ensure that average real funding levels are maintained to the 3008 services around Australia and that more places are available across the country.
The 1 July 1999 rates increases are part of an annual indexation of subsidies and supplements.

The Productivity Commission's report on Nursing Home Subsidies was tabled in Parliament on 31 March 1999. The report endorses the Government's objective of uniform national subsidies for residential aged care.
The Government is in the process of consulting with consumer and industry representatives prior to a whole of Government decision on the recommendations and the way ahead.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Diesel Fuel

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) and the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government (Senator Ian Macdonald) to questions without notice asked by Senators West, Murphy and Mackay today, relating to the proposed diesel fuel rebate.

I doubt very much whether the producers of the well respected newsletter Inside Canberra would be very flattered by being called Labor stooges or whatever term the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government (Senator Ian Macdonald) used. I appreciate that the minister may not be feeling well today but I still do not think that there was an excuse to do that.

Just let me advise the Senate precisely what the analysis that Inside Canberra have undertaken says. To restate this, essentially what they are saying is that the excise savings on diesel will equate to a saving of only 0.33 of a cent in the dollar on food costs in rural and regional Australia. For example, if you buy a basket of groceries for $10, you receive a 3.3 per cent savingâand that is only if the transport operators actually do pass on the costs, and we saw the interchange between the minister and Senator Cook in relation to that. The figure is calculated on the fact that the diesel rebate will lower operating costs by 32 per cent. But only 21 per cent of a truck's operating costs relate to fuel and oil; 32 per cent of 21 per cent equals 6.5 per cent, which therefore equates to a retail saving to the consumer of 0.33 of a cent in the dollar. So that is how they derive their figures.

Interestingly, Senator Macdonald, in his response, essentially said, `It is the right way to goâreduce costs et cetera,' but what he failed to doâand I think it would be germane for the government to undertake thisâwas provide its modelling in relation to savings in rural and regional Australia and, in relation to the assertions made by the publication Inside Canberra, prepare a refutation of those assertions. I would ask Senator Macdonald to take that on notice. If he would do so, that would be very useful. He has made no serious attemptâas has no government minister, including Senator Kempâto refute not simply these allegations but allegations that have been made previously. Nor has any government senator or minister made any serious attempt to table or provide information with regard to the government's own modelling in terms of the savings that it is asserting will occur.

Under the government's new legislation, which of course is the result of the deal with the Democrats, the reduced diesel excise will apply to all trucks of 20 tonnes and over and to trucks over 4.5 tonnes which operate in rural and regional Australia. Accordingly, some 60,000 petrol-powered trucks over 4.5 tonnes will receive no benefit whatsoever. Some legal authoritiesâand we heard the question earlier todayâbelieve that the inequality of treatment could raise questions about breaches of section 92 of the Constitution, and that has had quite a lot of airplay recently.

talk.start.para: âWho wrote this for you, Sue?

âI did. This legislation is a compliance nightmare, and it has had a lot of air coverage in relation to the potential abuse that this scheme will come under. The reason it is a nightmare is that businesses have the capacity to simply change their base of operations so they are located on the regional side of what is an arbitrary boundary line by altering their delivery patterns to obtain the maximum benefits from the scheme. What is the government's response to this? They simply announced huge fines. They say it will not happen because there will be huge fines if people do transgress the arbitrary boundaries which have been determined.

speech.para: This is obviously going to result in distortions of market patterns. This is obviously going to result in disparities in relation to rural and regional Australia, and it is obviously not going to get what the government wants, which are reduced costs in terms of transport and, therefore, consequential costs in terms of food. I think it is incumbent upon the government to answer a serious question from the opposition as to whether the allegations are correct and as to whether the issues that have been brought to bear by a number of organisations in terms of the potential breaches are correct. I do not think it is reasonable for the government to simply say, `We won't give you the modelling,' or, more likely, `We haven't done the modelling.' If there was modelling doneâif the savings can be realisedâwe want to see the figures. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIf ever there was anyone on a hiding to nothing, it is Senator Mackay. I cannot understand where she is coming from. This package is the greatest thing that has ever happened to rural and regional Australia. It delivers a 23c reduction in the excise. Some of these large prime movers do about one kilometre to the litre. A 23c reduction in the excise means it will be 23c a kilometre cheaper to run transport in rural Aus tralia, not to mention the 22 per cent reduction in sales tax.

speech.para: After this package was negotiatedâand I will just take Senator Mackay on a little tour of QueenslandâI went to Warwick, Goondiwindi, Bundaberg, Rockhampton and Kingaroy. When I presented this package to the transport operators out there, the universal message that came through was, `This is too good. We are not going to be able to retain all the extra profits. We are going to have to renegotiate our contracts.' That was spontaneous, and it went right across all those country towns.

Senator Mackay, it seems that the Labor Party has fallen into the greatest phase of negativity. You knock everything, you are against everything, and then you introduce some red herring that 60,000 petrol trucks will not be able to participate in the reduction of the fuel excise. That is trying to pull everything down to the lowest common denominator, and that is probably where the Labor Party is coming from. The coalition, on the other hand, is trying to provide benefits for rural and regional Australia, and this is going to reduce the costs on exports by $4.5 billion. You have only to mention it out there, as Senator Ian Macdonald would have done in his visits around rural Australia, and people in rural and regional Australia get absolutely excited about the prospect of cheaper fuel costs, the reduction in export costs of $4.5 billion, and the reduction in sales tax by 22 per cent on prime movers and trailers.

One particular place in Kingaroy has 12 prime movers at a cost of $250,000 each, which amounts to a $50,000 saving. The trailers are about $180,000 each, which is a $36,000 saving, and then there is a 23c per kilometre reduction in diesel. Yet you come in here and say that it is not going to benefit rural and regional Australia. You are totally off the planet. Madam Deputy President, you are trying to turn a sow's ear into a silk purse, because this is the greatest silk purse, or the other way aroundâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Boswell, please address the chair. I am personally not trying to turn a sow's ear into a silk purse.

âMadam Deputy President, Senator Mackay, the shadow minister for local government, is trying to turn a silk purse into a sow's ear, and this is the greatest silk purse that has been given to rural and regional Australia. I suggest that Senator Mackay goes out and has a talk to some of her rural constituents, and then she will come in here and sing a completely different tune. If you want to be critical, there are probably some things you can attack on, but certainly not this. You have really let your side down, Senator Mackay, because you have picked the greatest bonus ever given to rural Australia and you have come in here and bucketed it. All that proves is that you do not understand regional and rural Australia. You have not got a clue. You are disconnected from your blue-collar workers out in regional and rural Australia. For goodness sake, go out there and reconnect with them. Go out and have a talk to them on occasions, and then you will not come in here, let your side down and drop the ball, because this is the greatest benefit that has ever been presented to regional Australia.

talker.name: Senator GEORGE CAMPBELL
Senator GEORGE CAMPBELL
talker.role: UNKNOWN

talk.start.para: âI also want to take note of the answers given by the coalition with respect to the diesel fuel rebate. It was interesting to hear Senator Boswell's contribution on this matter, because everything that this government has introduced since I have been in this Senate has been `the greatest thing that has ever happened to regional and rural Australia', knowing full well that, on many of the issues that have come before this chamber, Senator Boswell, his colleagues and his partners in the National Party have been party to selling out the interests of people in regional and rural Australia.

speech.para: They have done it on a whole range of issues which they have supported in this chamber. In fact, if you talk to some of them privately they will admit to you that they got worse than they could have got out of some of the deals that they have done with their coalition partners. They will not publicly stand up and defend the position of the constituency that they purport to represent. That is why in two or three days time there will be fewer of you in this chamber than there are today. There will be fewer of you because you have not had the courage to represent your constituency on the range of issues that have come before this government that deal with regional and rural Australia.

I want to come back to the issue of the diesel fuel rebate. It was interesting that Senator Kemp avoided answering questions about the constitutionality of the arrangement with the Democrats. He avoided answering whether or not the government was looking at the constitutional question. The reality is that there are significant constitutional questions in relation to whether or not this so-called scheme that has been put together with the Democratsâtheir new-found partners in crimeâwill in fact hold up if it is challenged constitutionally. It may well be that, at the end of the day, the people in the corner who say they represent regional and rural people will in fact finish up with a pig in a poke if this legislation is challenged in terms of its constitutionality.

The second point is that it is discriminatory. It discriminates against a significant section of the community who are in regional and rural Australia. It excludes whole areas of the community from participation in the scheme.

talk.start.para: âWho?

âLet me tell you. It excludes people in the Brisbane-Gold Coast-Sunshine Coast strip but it does not exclude Tweed Heads. Why not Tweed Heads? What is the difference between Tweed Heads and the Sunshine Coast and the Gold Coast? It is only five minutes down the road. Why the arbitrary distinction between Tweed Heads and the Gold Coast? It excludes people in Newcastle, Sydney, Wollongong, Melbourne, Geelong, Adelaide, Perth and Canberra. Why, for example, should diesel trucks in Goulburn be included in the scheme and diesel trucks in Geelong be excluded from the scheme?
âIs that true?

âOf course it is true. Haven't you read the legislation? You are in here defending it, Senator McGauran, and you are probably one of the people who will get up on their feet in this chamber in the next 20 minutesâ

âOrder! Senator George Campbell, address the chair, please. Senator McGauran, you know that interjections are disorderly. Unless the whips have changed the seating allocations, you are not in your correct seat. So you should not be even saying a single, solitary word, thank you very much.

âSenator McGauran will probably be one of the people who gets up in this chamber in the next 20 minutes to defend the scheme, when it is obvious that he has not even read it. He does not even know what the contents of the scheme are or how it is going to apply.

speech.para: In the time that is left to me I will briefly look at some of the examples about how this is going to be managed. Some of the proposals for measuring whether people are complying with this scheme or not border on the ridiculous. Some of the suggestions are that they might have log books, they might have an allocation of special number plates or they might have different coloured oils. What we might actually see are diesel trucks going through capital cities and metropolitan cities blowing out green smoke to signify that they do not get the rebate and, when they are driving out in the country, we will see blue or yellow smoke pouring out of the diesel trucks to signify that they are getting the diesel rebate. It is absolutely ridiculous. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe Labor Party are at it again. All they come in here and do every question time is carp and carp. They make no positive contribution to debate and have no policies of their own. They remain a policy-free zone. Today, of course, they are trying to diminish one of the main benefits of tax reform that has been initiated by the Liberal and National Party coalition government, and that is a substantial reduction in fuel costs for the transport industry and, as a consequence of that, a much needed reduction in the overall cost of transport.

speech.para: The government is providing a reduction of 23c a litre in the price of diesel fuelâa massive reduction in the cost of fuelâfor those qualifying trucks. Those trucks are, of course, trucks that have a total weight in excess of 4Â½ tonnes operating in rural and regional areas of Australia and those trucks with a total weight in excess of 20 tonnes operating anywhere in Australia, whether that be rural and regional areas or the metropolitan areas. That is a substantial benefit for the transport industry of Australiaâa benefit that stands undiminished by this pathetic attempt by this pathetic Labor opposition to diminish it.

On top of that, all vehicles used for business purposes will have fuel reduced by the order of 6c or 7c because they will qualify for a rebate on the GST they pay on fuel. Whether it is diesel, petrol or whatever fuel source, all those vehicles used for business purposes will have a reduction in fuel costs of that order. What we need to remember is that this is what the transport industry itself sought in their discussions with the government when we were developing our tax package over the last year or two. The transport industry put forward very strongly the view that a substantial reduction in the cost of fuel would make an important contribution towards lowering their costs.

This Liberal-National Party government have delivered in full on the commitment we made to the transport industry and, as we well know, the transport industry is very satisfied with what we have delivered in this instance. So let us have no more of this carping from this pathetic opposition, which really does not know what it is talking about in relation to transport. The government have made a substantial reduction in the tax on fuel.

Not only have we done that for the transport industry, but we have also abolished the wholesale sales tax; and that has been another significant cost for the transport industry. The high levels of wholesale sales tax that have applied on trucks, spare parts for trucks, tyres and batteries are all gone; they are not there anymore. They have been replaced by a GST at 10 per cent which, for these trucks, because they are all used for business purposes, will be fully rebated.

talk.start.para: âAnd air-conditioning.

âAll of the parts and accessories that go into trucks used for business purposes in the transport industry in Australia will have that wholesale sales tax removedâthe legislation has passed, but for the third reading to comeâand replaced with a fully refundable GST. This is a substantial reduction in operating costs for the transport industry.

speech.para: All we have from the Labor Party as a response is this carping effort today in question time and in this debate. They have no policy initiatives of their own on the issue. They remain a completely policy-free zone with regard to tax reform and with regard to the important issues facing Australia. Let us remember that when they were in government they actually sought to increase the costs that were going to be imposed on heavy transport in rural and isolated areas. I well remember the inquiry that we conducted in the then Senate transport and infrastructure committee which highlighted the increase in cost that was going to be initiated by the then Labor government. This government, in contrast, has reversed that and is actually doing something to reduce the cost of transport in this country.

Australia is an enormous country geographically and it has a relatively small population concentrated in particular areas. Therefore, transport is a very important factor in Australia, and the cost of transport makes up a much bigger proportion of the cost of production in Australia than it does in other countries. Therefore, to get rid of the taxes on transport is a very important initiative in reducing the cost of transport and ultimately reducing the cost of the goods that require transport from their place of manufacture to their place of market, whether it is within Australia or, very importantly, from the places of production in Australia to the ports for export to earn more export dollars for Australia. That is the benefit this government has delivered. It is also delivering a benefit for the rail industry by all taxes being eliminated on fuel for the rail industry. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOn the same matter, can I just point out to the Senate that, contrary to what Senator Chapman just said, it is a pity that he, like his National Party colleagues, had not read this legislation. It really is a pity, because he would then understand exactly what it is all about and would not get up and make statementsâmisleading statements, I might addâas he just did when he said that, for trucks in excess of 20 tonnes, you are entitled to the rebate anywhere in Australia. Not so. The government's explanatory memorandum on the bill says:

speech.para: The grant will be available for on road use of these fuels in vehicles with a gross vehicle mass of 4.5 tonnes to 20 tonnes used for transporting goods or passengers. However, for vehicles under 20 tonnes, the grant is not available for the sole use of the relevant fuels in the following metropolitan areas:
That is what it means, Senator Chapman.
Senator Chapman interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThat is not what you said. Madam Deputy President, this is from the government which said we would never, ever have a GST. The Prime Minister from Never-Ever Land said we would never have a GST, and we now have a proposal for a diesel fuel rebate scheme. When I asked Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer, for an explanation of the compliance costs, he did not answer me. If you read the explanatory memorandum, it says:

speech.para: Compliance cost impact : Medium.
It is a bit like a steakhouse: well done, medium, underdone. What is the compliance cost? The explanatory memorandum goes on further to say that the compliance cost will be negligible or the same.

They have introduced a whole new range of categories and expect thatâas Senator George Campbell was pointing outâthere will be different coloured smoke depending on whether you are in a metropolitan area or a country area. Who knows? How are you going to maintain any sort of surveillance of this system? We have heard that we will have a geographic positioning system. We will be plotting these little trucks wherever they go; their mapping system will come in. How ridiculous! It costs something in the order of $12 million per year to administer the current scheme, and the Auditor-General's office has found that the current scheme has been subject to an extreme amount of rorting. How are you going to tell the Australian taxpayers that the scheme that you propose now is going to be rorted less? You cannot, and that is why the minister could not answer the question on compliance costs. That is why you have got all sorts of trouble, and of course when you are in all sorts of trouble, what do you do? You come in here and you defend hard, but you defend in a nonsensical way, because you do not read your billâyou do not even read the explanatory memoranda.

The shadow minister in the other chamber gave an example from the explanatory memorandum about a vehicle that is being set up to claim this rebate. Talking about that example of Vicki's furniture removal business, Ms Kernot said:

Vicki is based in Forbes. She drives from Forbes to Sydney to pick up some furniture. That consists of a journey to a metropolitan area from a point outside it. Clearly, for that part she is entitled to the grant. Then she delivers the furniture to Dubbo. That is a journey from a metropolitan area to a point outside it, so she is eligible for the grant for that journey. Then she drives home to Forbesâthat is a journey entirely outside a metropolitan area, so she gets the grant for that as well. On one reading, this seems to suggest that each separate leg of the journey is going to count as a separate journey.

Ms Kernot goes on to ask the minister to confirm whether, if furniture is delivered within the city as part of that journey, you are entitled to the grant. And what happens if you base your business just outside the metropolitan areas mentioned in the explanatory memorandum, or if you work in the city and then go home just outside? How do you deal with those sorts of situations? There is no explanation from the government, and that is just how stupid this system is.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The time for the debate has expired.

interjection.para: Senator Kemp interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Kemp, interjections are unruly and certainly out of order when you are not in your place and not even seated. The question is that the motion moved by Senator Mackay be agreed to.
