talk.start.para: âWe now have one hour to debate 22 bills, so in one hour we have just over two minutes per bill. These are bills relating to quite extensive matters of the GST and the application of it as far as tax cuts are concerned, and to a range of other things too numerous for me to quickly cover. They involve the wine equalisation tax, the luxury motor vehicles tax and a whole series of things, including the Australian business number, and bills relating to the ACCC.

speech.para: I have once again to protest that it is ridiculous in the extreme to deal with such complex and numerous bills all at once within an hour, when there are several amendmentsâsome of them by the governmentâthree of which have now been moved to its own legislation, and when no explanation as to the purpose of the amendments has been given by the government. They just move them, sit down, shut up and say nothing further to the chamber.

talk.start.para: âI'll get up and talk it out, then. You were complaining yesterdayâ
âMinister, order!
âYesterday was Sunday.
âAll right, you wait. I'll get up and talk it out.

âI am not inviting you to get up and talk it out, Minister. You know that all too well. What I am once again drawing attention to is that, when this new Democrats-government GST package came before the chamber, we asked the government and the Democrats to make a statement as to the significance of their changes, to save us having a statement made each time, and they declined to do so. So we are debating blind, without the proper information before us, in an effortâon a joint guillotineâto rush this legislation through.

speech.para: I make this pointâand let me mark the spot in making itâthat, if there are therefore errors in this legislation which proper debate would have otherwise detected, then the fault is the government's and the Democrats'. When people in the Australian community have the obligation of dealing with these laws that we are so quickly rushing through this Senate, the fault will be entirely that of the government and the Democrats, and there will not be acceptable in public debate any argument from the government or the Democrats that somehow or other it is Labor's fault. Let it be known now. Let the spot be marked right now, that the fault is the government's and the Democrats' as far as the errors go that will surface in this legislation.

The first and most important of all of this legislation that we have to consider is that embodying tax cuts. The tax cuts are large cuts. I think, though, that there is an issue here of fairness and equity considerations in the manner in which these tax cuts are given. Let me make one point before I turn to some of the inequities that are apparent on the schedule, once you look at where the tax cuts fall and who gets the benefit of them.

The first point is this. We are introducing a new tax, a GSTâsomething that Labor opposes but that the Democrats and the government want. That will impose extra costs on the Australian community. As a way of offsetting the extra costs on ordinary Australian citizens, the government is providing, by way of compensation, cuts to the taxation scales. They will market those cuts as being a handout from the government to the community but, whenever they do speak about that, one should remember that this is compensation for a new taxâa new tax on everything, a new tax in the form of a GST which, if you look at the historical record, is a tax which always increases over time and never decreases.

So these compensations, to the extent that they are real, are to compensate for a tax which will rise over time. That is always what happens with a GST. But the compensation will remain fixed. Worse than that, the compensation will erode, because we do know that bracket creep, or the workings of inflation on wages, pushes wage and salary earners to higher incomes but not higher real money incomes and pushes them into different tax brackets so that, when they get pushed up the scale on bracket creep, they are obliged to pay higher taxes. The net effect is that the real value of their income erodes over time, unless you compensate for bracket creep in terms of your tax scales. Do these tax scales compensate for that? No, they do not.

So the two realities, the two grim reapers, of the GST are, firstly, the fact that it always increasesâthat is a historical record around the world wherever a GST has been introduced, and the elaborate mechanism to fool Australians into believing that it will not do so in Australia is of course a farce; it will increase here. And the second grim reality is that the tax cuts erode and therefore the compensation to offset for Australians the so-called higher costs and charges of a GST go down irretrievably as a consequence of the working of the taxation system. So when government spokespeople get up and say, `Look how munificent we are, how bountiful we are. Look at what we are giving to the Australian community,' one must remember always that the tax goes up and the compensation goes down, and that is a historical record.

Having made that point, I turn to the nature of some of these tax cuts. As I do so, I point out that we are going to vote for these tax cuts, because we do think Australians need relief now that this chamber has voted for a 10 per cent GST. We do think Australia needs some relief, and that is why we are going to vote for them. But we do not think that these tax cuts embody sufficient or appropriate relief. I go to two examples of what I mean in terms of equity. The personal income taxes that we are considering favour the rich and work against middle and low income Australians. Some examples from the tables published in the Weekend Australian the Saturday before last were worked out by the two pre-eminent economists in this field, Professor Warren and Professor Harding, and give the lie to the government claims about equity. I take two examples. A single income couple with one child, receiving $35,000 a year, receives a so-called total benefitâthat is, a total tax cutâof $17.80 per week. If that same family were to receive $70,000, not $35,000, it would get a total benefit of $77.19. So the family on the lower income gets $17; the family on the higher income gets $77.19. Of course, they are paying the same price for the goods and services they consume, because this is a flat tax. It charges people the same price, irrespective of their income. And it is irrespective of their income on this basis: if you get 70 grand, you get $77; but if you get only 35 grand, you get only $17. And they say this is fair.

One can look at the gross figures. Gross money figures tell one sort of story. Let us look at it another way: in terms of percentages. A $17.80 tax cut as a percentage of $35,000âI have not done the sumsâis just over a five per cent share of the total amount. But on $70,000, $77 is just over 10 per cent. So if you get a higher income, you get a higher percentage as well as more money; if you get a lower income, you get a lower percentage, despite less money. And they say this is fair.

Remember this: the doyens of so-called fairness, the people who thump their chests and claim to be compassionateâand indeed the government has now adopted the Texas view of compassionate conservatism that George Bush Jr is campaigning on in the US primaries, a phrase coined in the United States and suddenly adopted in Australia; it does not mean anything and it has no substance to it but it has a nice ring on televisionâthe so-called compassionate conservatives of the government are saying that is fair.

But with respect to those who have raised themselves on the edifice of so-called fairness, the Australian Democrats, this is their package too. They reckon that it is fair. We all remember what they said when they went into negotiations with the government. What did they say? They said they would start to smooth out the inequities of the tax cuts. Did they? Well, they did a bit. But did they do it properly? Not at all. What they did was fiddle at the top end of the scaleâand we welcome those changes. Do they go to the level of real need in the community? No, they do not. It is a bit of window dressing to say, `Well, we changed the system.' What did they give as their explanation for not doing the job properly? `Mr Howard refused. Mr Howard did not agree.' The Australian Democrats have to take the responsibility for this. Mr Howard did not agree because they did not insist. This legislation will not pass this chamber unless they vote for it. They had the ideal negotiating position. They could have said, `I am sorry, Mr Howard. That is inequitable. That is unfair. We will not vote for your package unless you restore some equity to the tax scales. Make it better than this.' Did they do that? They may have done, because it was behind closed doors, but John Howard stared them down and they bought the package at the end of the day, and therefore they own the inequities and unfairness in this package.

I give you another example: a dual income familyâtwo wage earners with one childâthat receives $35,000 a year gets tax cuts of $8.59 per week. Two income earners with one child on 35 grand per yearâthese are not people who earn a lot of money; these are people on the lower end of the income scale in Australiaâget an $8.59 per week tax cut. The same familyâa dual income family with one childâon $100,000 receives a weekly benefit of $75.56. So if you are poor, you get less. If you are getting $100,000 per year, you get more. In percentage terms again: the higher the income you get, the bigger the percentage of rebate you get; the lower the income you get, the lower the percentage. So not only in money terms but also in percentage terms this package is inequitable. And this is the embodiment of fairness and equity as far as the Australian Democrats and the national coalition led by John Howard are concerned, because this is what they are doing.

What has Mr Howard said about this? One of the things he has said which is most illuminating is that he is going for middle Australia and that he wants to reward effort. Well, middle Australia are entitled to some tax relief, because middle Australia are the ones that are pushed into higher income brackets by bracket creepâthe matter I spoke about earlier. But there is no excuse, when you go up these scales to $150,000 and $200,000 a year, for those people to still be getting big handouts when the poor at the other end of the scale are getting miserly handouts. Remember, as I said, that the tax goes up and the compensation erodes with time, so the first victims of the erosion with time effect of the compensation will be those at the bottom end of the scale. And they say this is fair.

I am one of those Australians who believe that a fair go for all is a basic right of all Australians. It is part of our folklore and what makes up our national character. Australians will say, `This is not fair.' While many of us at the higher levels of the income scales will benefit from this, and I will be one of themâI will benefit better than a lot of low income earnersâI still think it is not fair and that the rights of low income earners ought to be protected. Remember this: low income earners spend every cent they earn and they have nothing left over to save. So they have no capacity to find extra funds within their miserly household budgets. They are always stretching to try to meet the needs of the day, to accommodate extra costs.

What will this tax do? It will impose extra costs on these people. Why therefore do we need to have regard to the ability of welfare organisations to service the poor? In part it is because what this government-Democrats' package is doing is pushing them further down the trap into poverty. I say, `Okay, you have got away with a GST. This chamber has voted to impose one against the opposition of the Australian Labor Party. The very least you can do, if you have a bone of decency in your body, is to restore some equity to the income tax scales. Do not go chasing votes by trying to bribe people into supporting the GST, by giving the influential end of the income scales a higher handout so they will speak more proudly about a GST while ignoring the complaints at the lower end of the income scales.' This amounts to a vote bribe to support the GST by those at the wealthy end of the scale without regard to those at the other end of the scale.

As I said, there are some 22 bills that I have to debate now in less than three-quarters of an hour. We are considering the first one and I have not dealt with it comprehensively. The light is on; I will have to sit down shortly. There are a number of other bills which I think deserve a particular amount of attention. I hope that the government and the Democrats do not try to soak up the remaining minutes of this debate so that we cannot get our viewpoint across. I would hope that the next call goes to my colleague Senator Sherry so he can deal with the inequities in the wine industry. I would hope that when Senator Conroy comes in here in a minute we can deal with the ACCC. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThere are just a couple of issues that I would like to point out to Senator Cook. Firstly, I go back to 1993. We touched on these issues before but, after what he has said today, he obviously was not listening. I remind him that when the Labor Party dealt with tax cutsâthey were the last ones to do soâback in 1993, they looked at the issue of bracket creep and did not give any tax cuts to those earning under $20,700. There was no immediate compensation of any description for pensioners. Indeed, pension changes were delayed for many months. From memory, they were delayed for about eight months.

speech.para: I say to Senator Cook: look again at what the Labor Party did and in particular look at the fact that the maximum tax cuts went to those earning over $50,000âin other words, a similar situation to the one we are considering now concerning bracket creep. I point out that it is a separate issue from compensation for the GST. As we deal with bracket creep, we need to look at those areas where people jump into the higher brackets, and that comes back to the same area that Labor dealt with. But at least this time we are also seeing considerable tax cuts for those earning under $20,700. This time it is a very different story. I will go into more detail in a moment, but I remind Senator Cook that this time those earning over $100,000, on average, will be paying more tax.

The amendments that we are considering now revise the tax scales that were in the original ANTS package. The Australian Democrats are very pleased with what we have achieved. We did not achieve everything we set out to achieve, but certainly we have seen changes above the $50,000, and now the top marginal rate cuts in at $60,000 rather than the original government proposal of $75,000. This measure will save us $1.3 billion. That will go towards the cost of taking food out of the GST which itself is a very progressive move and benefits those on low incomes the most.

It is a very long time since we last revised our tax scalesâit goes back to 1993. Indeed, it will be seven years by the time these changes come into place. That is too long. Perhaps something we can put on the government's agenda is that we look at indexation so we do not have this battle every three, five, seven years or whatever of making the adjustments as people creep up the scales and get into higher and higher tax brackets, that we look at indexation and put to rest once and for all this ongoing battle of who gave which tax cuts to whom.

From 1993 to 2000, average earnings will have risen around 30 per cent; in other words, they will have gone up from $31,780 for a full-time adult to around $42,000 in the year 2000. That means that average income earners now face a marginal tax rate of 43 per cent. It is already one of the highest rates in the world so, given the fact that we are not indexing, again we will have this problem occurring down the line and it will have to be dealt with. Since 1993, as wage inflation has pushed up earnings, bracket creep has delivered a windfall to the government. That windfall is now in the order of $8 billion a year, or nearly 10 per cent of our total tax collections. Indeed, the entire budget surplus can be attributed to bracket creep. I think that is unacceptable. Clearly, tax reform in the form of revision of the income tax scales is overdue. We had argued, and still say to government, that it could have been done separately from the GST and then we would have seen more clearly the need for compensation as opposed to the need to deal with this second issue.

The bill in its amended form will deliver $12 billion of income tax cuts in the year 2000, which is bracket creep plus the other four. We are prepared to support this because, under the new tax system, two-thirds of the funding for these tax cuts comes from base broadeningâsomething the Labor Party did not do. Indeed, they used the rise in wholesale sales tax to pay entirely for their tax cuts. This time we are paying for some two-thirds of them by doing things like tightening up the rules of the fringe benefits tax. That will see, again, $760 million going into the coffers in relation to social security measures.

An amount of $790 million will go into the coffers from taxing trusts as companies and $1.4 billion will be raised from business tax compliance measures. An amount of $2 billion will be raised from abolishing the savings rebate; $2.6 billion from new company tax payment arrangements; and $300 million from the deferred company tax payments and life insurers. So $7.7 billion is being paid for by those mostly at the top. They are the ones who are using a variety of arrangements for minimisingâlegally at the momentâthe amount of tax they are paying. So it hits high income earners the hardest. I cannot understand how Senator Cook does not seem to be able to understand this. The revised tax cuts will be skewed to benefit middle income earners, who have borne the brunt of bracket creep.

According to 1996-97 tax statistics, 88 per cent of taxpayers earn less than $50,000. They paid 60 per cent of the tax collected. They receive 67 per cent of the up-front tax cuts, but when other income tax measures are taken into account, they receive some 76 per cent of the net tax cuts. According to the 1996-97 tax statistics, 1.3 per cent of taxpayers earned over $100,000 per year and paid 12.4 per cent of tax. They receive just 4.3 per cent of the up-front tax cuts. But after the effects of all the tax measures are taken into account, taxpayers on over $100,000 a year, on average, will be paying more tax than they are now. Let me repeat that: when we put it all together and look at the base broadening and who that affectsâthe trusts and savings rebates; we roll all that in togetherâtaxpayers on more than $100,000 a year will be paying more tax than they are now. This is a direct result of the Democrats' insistence that tax cuts be pared back on incomes above $50,000.

The savings, as I said, are $1.3 billion and we left intact all the cuts for those at the bottom end of the system. The new top tax rate will cut in at $60,000, about 1.4 times average earnings. That compares with the last time that it was reviewed by Labor and set at $50,000, which was then 1.8 times average earnings. The bottom rate for incomes below $20,000 will be cut from 20 per cent to 17 per centâthe lowest rate for more than three decades. That is half the rate it was in the 1970s and lower than it ever was under a Labor government, so I am pleased to support this amended tax scales bill. We end up with a progressive tax system where high income earners on average end up paying more tax, low income earners enjoy the lowest marginal rates in decades and middle income earners get relief from bracket creep. That is a very worthy outcome.

I have to say that I would like to see more action on closing tax loopholes. Some issues have now been referred to the Ralph inquiry and I am pleased to see the allowance of an extra month for that report to come down. As part of our agreement with the Prime Minister and the government, what has gone over to the Ralph review includes the alternative minimum company tax proposals. We have particularly asked them to look at the United States model to reduce corporate tax avoidance and also the use of company structures and contracts to reduce the tax paid by personal service workers. Those two issues have gone to Ralph. These issues, and the reduction of the concessional treatment of company cars already being considered by Ralph, could raise an additional $2 billion a year. They are fights that we will leave for another time. I commend these amendments to the Senate.

talk.start.para: âThank you, Madam Chair.
âMadam Chair, I jumped to my feet well before Senator Sherry.
âUnfortunately, I called Senator Sherry.
âI did jump to my feet.
âSo did I, and I beat you.

âMadam Chair, you have now called two Labor speakers on this bill. All right, Senator Sherry, you speak and I will speak last. That is fine by me. Just so we do not make a mistake, Senator. I just record thatâ
âOrder, Minister! I called the person who jumped first.
âNo, you did not. You looked at that side and saw Senator Sherryâ
âAnd I beat you.
âBefore you looked at this side.
âOrder! I call on Senator Sherry.

âAs Senator Cook said, we are dealing with 22 bills and we have about 33 minutes left. I do not want to speak for the full 15 minutes, Senator Kemp. I will speak for about five minutes on the wine industry equalisation tax. I think it is a matter of great regret that, for this very important issue to one of Australia's fastest growing industries, we have got less than 35 minutes and it has not yet rated a mention in this debate. The Australian wine industry, as I think most people in Australia are aware, has seen tremendous growth over the last decade. It has become a world beater. It is a very important industry in the value adding of agricultural commodities: grapes. It is a top industry in the world in terms of quality. We now export $880 million of wine annually to more than 80 countries and the industry has an international reputation as an exporter of quality and premium wine at a competitive price.

speech.para: I think, unfortunately, that many in the wine industry believe that, with the government's proposals for a goods and services tax, the other taxes that apply on wineâthe excise taxes on alcohol generallyâwould either be abolished or at least be held at a level so that the price of alcohol would not go up once the GST is added. I believe that the Treasurer, Mr Costello, and the Liberals blatantly misled the wine industry about the level of the new taxânot just the GST but the new wine equalisation tax which is being introduced. The Winemakers Federation and the wine industry generally believed that the new wine equalisation tax would be revenue neutral, but of course that is not the case. The Liberals and Mr Costello have continued to mislead the wine industry, although very reluctantly and only recently, the Treasurer, Mr Costello, has conceded that the new wine equalisation tax will increase the industry's annual tax take by eight per cent.

The Winemakers Federation of Australia estimates that the new wine equalisation tax plus the GST will increase the wine industry's tax impost by $147 million a year. So the total tax take from the wine industry is going up significantly, about 12 per cent, according to Mr Sutton, Chief Executive Officer of the Winemakers Federation. He says that `this breaches an earlier government promise that the new tax system would have no significant effect on tax revenue'. This has caused grave concern in the wine industry for two basic reasons. First, the level of tax on wine in Australia is being increased significantly and Mr Sutton says:
. . . the government is pushing usâ
the wine industryâ
now into the rarefied position of being the most highly taxed wine growing country in the world and this is a massive increase in tax on one of Australia's most successful exporting industries.
This has drawn criticism. It is interesting to see that Senator Crane is not in the chamber. An article in the Financial Review said:
Senator Winston Crane (Lib)â
from Western Australiaâ

who is also chair of the Government's agriculture committee, said the wine tax policy could be `better and fairer'. Senator Crane said the Government's package should be supported when it is voted on in the Senate, but he called for `independent research' to be undertaken to determine the actual impact on the wine industry.

We know what the impact is going to be: a massive increase in tax on the wine industry. Secondly, because of that increase and the structure of the existing tax on wine, which is ad valorem, this will mean a significantly greater increase in prices for the higher priced, higher quality wineânamely bottled wineâand a lower price increase for cask wine.

This has some important policy implications. I would like to use, as an exhibit for the Senate, a cask of wine. I did not particularly pick on Morris wineries, but this particular issue of ad valoremâ

talk.start.para: âExhibit A.

âExhibit A. This particular issue of ad valorem tax on wine means that a cask of wine is about as cheap per litre as coca-cola. It is in fact cheaper than light beer per litre. That is an absurd outcome.

speech.para: It was with interest that I bought this cask of wine from the bottle shop. It says on the cask:
This pressing style wine is deep crimson red in colour, displaying rich ripe fruit aromas. The palate is generous and full flavoured with balanced tannins and a clean dry finish.

We have, on the side of the box, `five generations of wine makers' and `established in 1859'. When you look at the back of the box it says `product of Spain 95 per cent, Australia 5 per cent'. With the skewing of the wine tax to favour bulk wine, we are seeing significantly increased imports of bulk wine from overseas. That is one detrimental impact of this structure of the tax. The second issue relates to the health impact the sale of cheaper wine will have.

I want to reiterate that we are seeing an increase in the total wine tax, which is breaking the government's commitment. It is an extra $147 million. What is the Democrats' response? The Democrats claim they have a deal with the Howard government that will:
. . . ensure that the states keep arrangements which provide a tax exemption for cellar door and mail order sales up to $300,000.

That is the announcement by the Democrats. We would like an undertaking from the Democrats that that deal will be delivered, because apparently the Treasurer, Mr Costello, has left the wine industry floating in the wind, so to speak. The Treasurer has reiterated these arrangements. He says:
We will ensure that states will keep arrangements providing for rebates on cellar door and mail order sales for wineries up to $300,000.
But he then went on to say:
The states should be in a position to continue those rebate schemes. Indeed I understand that South Australia has already indicated that it will.

I would like Senator Lees, as a senator and the Leader of the Democrats, to explain why the South Australian state Treasurer, Mr Bob Lucas, a Liberal, when asked about Federal Treasurer Costello's assurances, said, `No, it is not true. We have not been consulted, so at this stage we cannot agree to anything.' This very important industry for Australiaâa particularly important industry for South Australiaâand the Democrats have been conned. It is an outright lie. This lie is being clearly illustrated by the false claims that the Treasurer of this country, Mr Costello, has made in respect of the application of this state.

talk.start.para: âMr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. It is quite clear that the use of the word `lie' is not appropriate or parliamentary. I suggest that it be withdrawn.

âOn the point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman: as you would be aware, Senator Sherry was not calling anyone a liar, which is unparliamentary, or saying that any individual had espoused a lie. He was talking about what was contained in a press release from Mr Costello as being an outright lie. I think there is a great deal of case law on this one.

âThank you, Senator Faulkner, I think you have made your point. I must ask Senator Sherry to withdraw because he was implying that the Treasurer had lied. Before you begin again, Senator Sherry, you are aware of the standing orders in relation to exhibits in this chamber and so I would suggest that, if you have finished reading from the cask that you were using, you put it down and out of sight, because this is not a place where we have exhibits.

âIt was not a bad drop, I have to say, despite the fact that 95 per cent of it came from Spain. I withdraw that comment. The facts speak for themselves. The Treasurer of the country, Mr Costello, has said that he has an agreement with the Democrats that ensures the states will keep arrangements providing for rebates on cellar door and mail order sales for wineries up to $300,000. He then went on to say:

speech.para: The states should be in a position to continue those rebate schemes. Indeed I understand that South Australia has already indicated it will.

But what does the South Australian state Treasurer, Mr Costello's own Liberal colleague, say? He says, `No, it is not true.' So someone is leading someone up the garden pathâor up the vineyard path perhaps is more appropriate. The facts speak for themselves with regard to the integrity of the Treasurer, Mr Costello, and the integrity of the South Australian state Treasurer. We want some assurances from the Democrats, because this particular arrangement concerning the $300,000 in cellar door sales does do something for small wineries, and it should be incorporated in the legislation. It should not rely on a fuzzy, hazy lack of commitment and the promise in the deal being entered into by Mr Costello and the Democrats, who have sold out the wine industry in this country.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP

talk.start.para: âSenator Cook complained that I had not spoken in this debate, so I will accept the invitation. I was actually trying to provide more time for Senator Cook, but as he chose to complain about it I will make a few remarks. The spleen which the Labor Party is showing is quite astonishing. This is a party without any policies, a party which has made no contribution to the tax debate and a party which has not raised any alternatives. It has come into the chamber and attempted to block a series of bills. It is worth recording, in the interests of the public, that the Labor Party is now complaining about the largest income tax cuts in Australian history. That is what the Labor Party is complaining about.

speech.para: If you look at Senator Cook's speech, you will see that the Labor Party is complaining that we are giving massive tax cuts. Despite what you say, Senator Cook, a fair assessment of the tax cuts that we are giving reveals that huge benefits flow to low and middle income earners. This is not just the assessment I am making; this is the assessment of independent observers. If you look at the modelling carried out by Warren and Harding or by Access Economics you will see that we are providing massive tax cuts to lower and middle income Australia.

Let me outline the scale of some of these tax cuts. There are two examples which are perhaps worth recording in Hansard. This is the advice I have received. It relates to a single income family with two children between five and 13 and an income of $30,000. That is not a high income; it is lower than average weekly earnings. Warren and Harding, independent modellers, I am advised, calculate that this family will end up with an extra $49 in its pocket every week. Senator Cook comes up and sneers at it. The Labor Party has never given a tax cut like that in Labor Party history. That is not the government arguing that case; that is the advice I have received on what Warren and Harding calculated.

Access, another independent modeller, estimated that the benefit to this family is $59 per week. This is an increase of over $3,000 per year after GST. These are not small derisory tax cuts; these are very substantial tax cuts which are giving very real benefits to people on low incomes. Let us look at a single income family with one child under five and an income of $30,000âless than average weekly earnings. Access, the independent modellers, calculate an extra $54 per week. That is a very substantial rise. Warren and Harding calculate an extra $44 per week. These are very substantial tax cuts. These are of great benefit to low and middle income Australia.

Senator, you stand up and attempt to mock those cuts when the Labor Party offered nothing. You know that the truth of the matter is that, when this bill goes through, the Labor Party will be revealed as a party without policy and direction and as a party whose whole policy strategy has come unstuck. Your attempt to block major tax reform will be exposed for what it is. The one reason for the spleen and sheer nastiness coming from Senator Cook in this debate in the chamber is the realisation that you have failed in the task which you set yourself. You failed in the last election and you have failed in your efforts to make this government break its promises at the last election. Senator Cook, the public will judge you and your colleagues harshly, I believe.

What did the Labor Party want to do in the last election? The Labor Party wanted to impose a capital gains tax on pre-1985 assets. That is essentially what your policy was. Of course, days after the election you junked that because it was a nonsense. Let me give you an example of what Labor promised at the election. Consider a family with two parents earning $35,000 eachâaround average weekly earningsâand with three dependent children.

talk.start.para: âMr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. The bill before the chamber is a bill for tax cuts that the government has proposed. The government has three amendments to its own legislation before us. The minister is speaking about none of that.
âYou should not be ashamed of your own policies; you are getting a free run.

âHe abuses question time by misrepresenting our policies and he is about to do it again. I suggest that, on the basis of relevance, you call him to order and ask him to address the issues before the chair. If he wants to debate our policyâin which we have no GST, so we do not have to compensate for itâI am happy to do that.
âThere is no point of order.

âOf course there is no point of order. What an astonishing thing. As Senator Boswell pointed out correctly, all I am trying to do is to indicate what the Labor Party policy is. Senator Cook knows what the answer is. Consider a family with, say, three children and both of the adults in the family earning $35,000 eachâa total family income of $70,000. Do you know what this family got from the Labor Party in tax cuts? Zero; absolutely nothing. That was your policy, Senator, and it is no wonder that you were beaten again at the election. Unless you improve your approach to politics, unless you are prepared to get in there and develop real policies, the public will judge you harshly again, as indeed they should.

speech.para: Constant abuse of people and constant attacks on the integrity of people are not a substitute for real policy. Real policy requires a bit of work. Above all, it requires some knowledge of what you believe in. And the great problem for the Labor Party, as I have said often in this chamber, is that the hardest question you could ask them is: what do you stand for? They do not know, and nobody else knows. Until you and your colleagues do some of the hard work and work out what you stand for and build on that and develop some real policies, Senator, I suggest that you will be over on that side of the chamber for a very long period indeed, and deservedly so.

Some issues regarding the wine equalisation tax were raised, so let me make some comments on that. The WET carries across the basic structure of the wholesale sales tax, so the practical change for taxpayers is minimal and generally improved. This will ensure that the principles underlying the WET are familiar and that the concepts underlying the legislation are well accepted by the industry. The WET will be integrated with the registration requirements for the Australian business number, the ABN, and this will be simpler and more consistent for business. The Commonwealth does not propose to rebate the WET on cellar door sales and samples, consistent with the existing practice where the Commonwealth provides no rebates under the wholesale sales tax.

The states and territories have maintained rebate schemes as part of the safety net arrangements introduced by the Commonwealth to replace business franchise fees that were of questionable constitutional validity. The states and territories receive goods and services tax revenue. After 1 July 2000 they will receive more revenue, including the funds that would have been raised by the safety net arrangements if they had continued to be in place. As a result, the states and territories will have sufficient funds under this tax reform to continue to provide rebates for wine tasting stocks, cellar door sales and mail-order sales.

talk.start.para: âWhy are you taking more tax from the wine industry?

âYou can huff and puff all you like, but as this debate draws to a close it is interesting to see just what a total impasse the Labor Party has reached. I thought Senator Lees made a very good point. In contrast to the changes that we are making to the indirect tax system this time, if you cast your mind back to 1993, I think Senator Lees was a bit kind. Not only were the tax cuts largely dropped, from memory, but no compensation was offered for the very large rise in wholesale sales tax and excise fees that the Labor Party brought in.
âThe tax cuts were brought forward.

âThe truth of the matter, Senator Cook, is that the Labor Party has got form on this issue and people do not like it. You have been talking about compensation packages which you do not happen to like, yet when you brought in your changes to the wholesale sales tax system no compensation was offered.
âWe provided a tax cut. Tell the truth.

âEveryone knows that you lied to the Australian public. It was the famous l-a-w law tax cuts which you dropped. To come in here and to lecture this government on tax reform after your appalling performance is absolutely risible. I do not accept any of the points that you have made. I accept the fact that you wanted me to make a statement, and I have made that statement.

speech.para: While I am on my feet, I want to point out that on Thursday, 24 June, during a stage of the debate on the ANTS package, I stated correctly that bread or buns with a sweet filling or coating would be subject to GST.

talk.start.para: âWe are being asked to look at the issue of tax cuts. I guess what we are being asked to believe is that this will make up for a lot of the damage that is going to be done to industry by this whole package. Senator Sherry brought up fervently the issue in relation to what is going to happen with the whole package, and especially the volumetric tax on the wine industry. I would like to add something to that argument. In the West Australian newspaper on Thursday, 24 June 1999, the editorial said:

speech.para: The fundamental flaw in the proposed new tax is that it is to be based on value rather than volume or alcohol content.
It also says:

The National Small Wineries Coalition has pointed out that 97 per cent of the nation's wine is produced by 20 big corporations and the rest by more than 1000 small businesses. It says 64 per cent of the big corporations' sales in Australia are of cask wine.
It also says:
Apart from its financial inequity, the WET proposed is unacceptable on the ground of public health.
It goes on to say:
And if the Australian Democrats really cared for small business the party would have supported a volume-based system, rather than push for another confusing tax exemption.
I could not agree more. The Independent Winemakers Association said:

The Australian wine industry faces a choice. It can continue under a socially irresponsible tax regime which punishes the pursuit of quality and rewards instead the mass production and import of cheap alcohol; or it can urge government to adopt a more sensible system which taxes alcohol and promotes the quality improvement demanded by an ever more discerning world market.

The volumetric tax advocated by the Independent Winemakers Association has full support from all major welfare, medical and drug authorities in Australia. It is simple and practical, and it gives a better deal to virtually all Australian grape and wine producers.
They go on to say:

Political decisions made now will show whether the government is serious in its fight against drugs, and prepared to support the industry's development as a responsible and economically valuable producer of health-giving quality wines; or whether on the contrary it will continue to pursue socially retrogressive policies, condemning the industry to future mediocrity and entrenching it as a legitimate target for anti-alcohol lobbies in the years to come.
I was very encouraged by the words of Senator Sherry. I hope that means that the ALP are now moving in their position on the WET. The National Small Wineries Coalition said:
During the last 15 years, successive Labor and Liberal Governments have imposed new taxes on the production of this agricultural product to the current 41%.
With their new-found influence the Democrats, for the first time, have joined these twoâ
and these are their wordsâ
rapacious and insensitive parties and this week announced that they will impose a new tax (WET), ratcheting up the total tax take from wineries to 49%.
They have tried to camouflage this black act with deceitful announcements that the rebate on cellar door sales provided by the states will continue.

In doing this, they have revealed the hollow nature of their action by capping this rebate to a ceiling of $300,000, that is 1500 cases of wine, that wineries can claim a 15% rebate on from their respective states, who have not even agreed to same.
It then says:
Meg Lees may finally meet her Waterloo following her own state, South Australia, announcing this morning that no such state arrangements were in place to support her hollow rebate gift.
This press release is dated 24 June 1999. If it has happened since then, we have not yet heard. In a press release that we received on 25 May, the National Small Wineries Coalition also said:
Clearly the big are benefiting at the expense of the small.

The Government, Democrats, Greens and Independents in their negotiations in respect to the GST have a golden opportunity to right the wrong that the WET proposal will inflict on society and small wine producers. To not do so will guarantee it becoming an electoral issue next time round.
I guess it will. In the Financial Review of 25 June, Paul Cleary said:
The agreement from the Democrats to pass the WET legislation is contingent on the Government delivering on the rebates, which are of major benefit to small wineries.

Labor MP Mr David Cox, who also owns a small vineyard in McLaren Vale, revealed that South Australian Treasurer, Mr Rob Lucas, said the State had not been consulted on the reforms and, as a result, could not commit itself to the rebates.
"We have not been consulted so we cannot agree to anything," Mr Lucas told an estimates hearing.

This tells the story, I am afraid. The wine industry has clearly said that. This was one of the strongest issues on which I have heard a clear consensus across various groupsâwelfare, alcohol, Aboriginal, health and, in particular, the quality wine producers and small wineries. This issue deserves better consideration but, unfortunately, it seems to have been passed over in the hope that somehow or other it will work out okay. I am afraid that that is not the way to make legislation.

I am very concerned about this. When we come to voting on these issues, I hope there will be some rethinking of the issues. I guess it is too late in relation to the Australian Democrats. I am hoping that we will get a good response from members of the opposition because they have made such strenuous comments in expressing concern about the way the Democrats have negotiated this particular issue.

âThe Commonwealth, states and territories are in agreement that the financial relationship between levels of government must be reformed and that Australia needs a stronger and more productive federal system for the next century. The government is committed to the reform of Commonwealth-state financial relations, and the two bills currently before the chamber will help to deliver this system. These bills represent an important step in improving the financial position of the states and territories.

speech.para: At the April Premiers Conference, the heads of government endorsed an intergovernmental agreement on the reform of Commonwealth-state financial relations. The Commonwealth, state and territory governments are in the process of revising that agreement to take account of the Prime Minister's 28 May announcement. This agreement retains the core elements of the original agreement and places Commonwealth-state financial arrangements on a more efficient and durable basis. Once agreed by all parties, this revised agreement will be attached to the legislation and the legislation will record the Common wealth's intention to comply with the agreement.

The amendments before us today are required to enact aspects of the reforms to the Commonwealth-state financial arrangements arising from these developments. The arrangements for transitional assistance are also modified to reflect the agreement reached between the Commonwealth and the states. The level of assistance to the states and territories will be increased to reflect the changes in the level of GST revenues that will accrue to the states and territories. Also, as agreed by the heads of government, the distribution of GST revenue grants will be solely on the basis of horizontal fiscal equalisation after two years. Following the 28 May announcement, responsibility for local government funding will be retained at the Commonwealth level. Amendments are now required to ensure that local governments can receive financial assistance grants from the Commonwealth. A number of other additional amendments are required to address some technical matters.

This probably brings to an end the debate to amend the bills for the government's tax reform package. There will be a debate on diesel tomorrow, but a raft of important bills will now be voted on by the Senate. Let me make it clear that this is a great day for Australia. The Senate has, we believe, produced a tax reform package which, with the passage of the legislation, will give Australia a tax system which will set it up for the new century. It is a tax system which reforms, among other things, the indirect tax system, the income tax system and the financial arrangements between the states and the Commonwealth. It provides major real improvements for people on pensions and benefits, and it provides huge assistance to families in particular, which this government has always had a particular focus on.

In my view, the efforts of the Labor Party to defeat tax reform in Australia show how far the Labor Party has fallen. The Labor Party refused to accept the mandate given to the government at the last election. We have been able to work very constructively with the Democrats. We have, I believe, produced a most effective tax reform package. As the weeks, months and years go by, I believe it will be very apparent what a momentous day this is for Australia. This is a day which has at last produced, after all the hard work over many years, major tax reform for this country.

I the undersigned hereby reject the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Online services) Bill as it currently stands and as has been passed by the Senate and respectfully request that the members of the House of Representatives and the Senate recognise:
That, for many Australians, the Internet plays a vital role as a means of communication, a vehicle for the expression of ideas and opinions, and a source of information.

That there is a need to make a clear distinction between the responsibility of those who produce and publish content and that of intermediaries such as carriers and Internet Service providers.

That the emerging information industries should not be burdened with unnecessary and poorly conceived regulation.

It will cause extensive damage to Australia's Internet industry, both access and content providers, raising costs for everyone.
Collateral damage accompanying the legislation will result in the blocking of all kinds of contentâand threats to personal privacy.
It will give us a more authoritarian regime than Singapore or Malaysiaâand make us the laughing-stock of the world.
I hereby call for the repeal of the legislation.
It is both unnecessary and dangerous.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That these bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speeches read as followsâ
DIESEL AND ALTERNATIVE FUELS GRANTS SCHEME BILL 1999

The Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Bill 1999 represents the fulfilment of commitments that the government made to Australia's rural and regional heartland in the lead-up to the 1998 election.

It is being introduced in conjunction with the Customs and Excise Amendment (Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme) Bill 1999, which implements changes to the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme that extend both the range of eligible uses and magnitude of benefits available under the Scheme, although not to the extent originally proposed by the government in A New Tax System.

In the lead-up to the last election, the government promised that the impact of the Goods and Services Tax on petrol and diesel prices would not just be offset by reductions in excise to ensure that the price at the pump need not rise.

Recognising Australia's dependence on transport due to the vast size of our continent, we also promised the price of our major transport fuel, diesel, would fall and fall very substantially, to the benefit of businesses and consumers; in particular for those people living in regional, rural and remote areas where transport costs are a significant part of the cost of living and doing business.

Under this bill, the Customs and Excise Amendment Bill, and the environmental expenditure package agreed between the government and the Australian Democrats, there will be large and enduring benefits to regional Australia, to the environment and to transport operators in the road, rail and marine sectors.

And, contrary to what has been asserted by the Opposition, the government has effectively quarantined regional Australia from the impact of the changes negotiated with the Democrats. The cost of road transport provided by all articulated vehicles and other trucks servicing regional areas will fall under these arrangements.
To the extent that compromises have been necessary, they have been driven by environmental concerns in the cities, and it is city-based transport that will necessarily now not receive the full gains.

Businesses across Australia will all pay less for fuel than they do now because they will get back the GST paid on inputs, including fuel. It is expected that businesses should save around six to seven cents per litre by this measure alone, although the actual amount will not be determined until next year after the final pre-GST CPI adjustment to excise rates.

In addition to the GST input tax credits on fuel purchased, the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grant Scheme will provide a further major cut in costsâwith grants in the order of 16 to 17 cents per litre of diesel used, for a wide variety of Australian businesses that provide transport services to country areas.
These include:
. interstate and city-country road transport;
. the transport of goods from all Australia's rural export regions and processing centres to their markets in the city or offshore;
. essential inputs being transferred from ports or factories in the city to the bush; and,
. the very bread and butter, indeed, all of the goods consumed by people living in country areas across this vast continent.
In addition to the grants available under this Scheme, which extend to cover alternative fuels, the government is extending concessions available under the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme.
The major additional benefits are:
. recognition of the rail industry as an off-road user of diesel and the consequent extension to rail operators of the full rebate of excise on diesel.
. extension of the full rebate for diesel and like fuels to marine use and other existing qualifying uses, including agriculture, fishing and mining.
. however, in the case of forestry, this industry will continue to have access to the rebate in the proportion it currently receives.
Madam President

The government's objective has always been to reduce the price of transport fuels for business, however, in order to honour the agreement reached with the Democrats, it is no longer possible to deliver this through the tax system.

As the intention is to offset costs for only a specified part of the transport fleet and its usersâthose servicing regional areas, the tax system isâon legal adviceâan inappropriate means by which to deliver the benefits. Thus, we will deliver this measure through a grants scheme.

In addition to this, the use of a broad-ranging grants scheme will make the transition to the new, long-term scheme of Energy Credits, foreshadowed in the bill, much easier, reducing the impact on industry of multiple changes to arrangements.

As agreed between the government and the Democrats, the grant for diesel use in prescribed vehicles and prescribed areas will be set so as to provide a cumulative reduction in the cost of diesel by around 23 cents per litre, when the GST input tax credits are added in.

The bill not only provides grants for diesel fuel use, but also covers alternative fuels, including CNG and LPG, canola, ethanol and recycled oil. Grant rates for each of these fuels will be established by regulation so as to maintain the current price relativities between them and diesel, given that unlike diesel, they are not subject to excise. Additional fuels may be added by regulation.

The grants will be potentially available for all road transport vehicles above 4.5 tonnes, however, fuels used in vehicles between 4.5 tonnes and 20 tonnes Gross Vehicle Mass will qualify only in the following circumstances:
. if the vehicle is engaged in transporting goods or passengers within regional Australia;
. between a metropolitan area and a regional point (and vice-versa); or
. between metropolitan areas on an interstate journey.

Fuel used in vehicles of 20 tonnes or more Gross Vehicle Mass will qualify if used by a business for road transport, and if the business is registered for the purposes of the Scheme with the Australian Tax Office.
The explanatory memorandum accompanying the bill contains some examples of qualifying journeys and I commend it to Senators.

Senators will recall that previously the ANTS package had proposed that diesel fuel credits be available to vehicles of 3.5 tonnes GVM or greater, however, this had the potential to encourage business operators to switch to heavier vehicles in order to capture the benefits of the diesel fuel credits. The result could also have been an unintended switch from petrol to diesel powered vehicles, with consequent increases in particulate emissions.

The use of 4.5 tonnes as the cut-off point under this bill for a grant scheme removes these unintended incentives. Four point five (4.5) tonnes is a natural cut-off point for vehicle classes because different licensing requirements apply at this levelâa truck driver's licence is needed to operate such vehicles.

In addition, very few transport vehicles use petrol at this new threshold. Some 99.9 per cent of articulated vehicles and 90.5 per cent of rigid trucks already use diesel, as do a similar percentage of the bus fleet. Thus, the scope for fuel switching in heavier vehicles is extremely limited under this bill.
In fact, viewed in the context of the full set of environmental commitments made by the government, particulates emissions in cities will actually fall substantially.

The Bureau of Transport Economics has estimated that, based on its projections of fuel use, reflecting anticipated growth in the national transport task, fuel use would have increased by approximately 50 per cent by 2015âand by more with the added economic stimulus of the tax package boosting national productivity and our export competitiveness.
As a result, there would have been a substantial increase in particulate matter emissionsâand I emphasise that this is the case with or without the new tax system.

In capital cities, where the health impacts and associated costs were likely to have been most noticed, this would have seen an increase from 5.7 Gigagrams of particulate emissions in 1997 to 10.3 Gigagrams by 2015.
With the establishment of
. standards for low sulphur diesel in 2002,
. incentives for the introduction of ultra low sulphur diesel from 2003
. the introduction of mandatory ultra low sulphur diesel standards from 2006, plus
. the vehicle emission standards to be determined and gazetted before this bill takes effect
it is now expected that particulate matter emissions across Australia will be no greater in 2015 than they were in 1997.
And in cities, where the issue is potentially at its most serious, pollutant levels should fall from the 5.7 Gigagrams noted earlier to 4.2 Gigagramsâa 26 per cent reduction.
I would like to underline what a great achievement this is when one considers the anticipated growth in the national transport task over this period that I have mentioned already.
Improved emission standards for both petrol and diesel vehicles are effectively incorporated into this bill.

Section 2 of the bill outlines the commitments we have given in this regard. The commencement of the act is contingent upon them being implemented in Australian Design Rules made under the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989.
Dates of application have been specifically incorporated in the bill at the request of the Democrats and I am repeating their intent today, because of the complexity of the subject.
The outline in the bill in substance recognises our obligations to apply
. Euro 2 emission standards to all new light diesel in 2002; and continuing models from 2003;
. Euro 3 to all new medium and heavy diesel models in 2002; and continuing models from 2003;
. Euro 4 to all new diesel models from 2006; and continuing models from 2007;
. Euro 2 to all new petrol models from 2003; and continuing models from 2004; and
. Euro 3 to new petrol models from 2005; and continuing models from 2006.

The exception noted in the Section 2 of the bill is important. Our vehicle industry would have serious difficulty coping with the application of standards under Euro 4 for petrol vehicles. We thus have yet to make a commitment in that area, and the legislation is intended to reflect this.
Overall, the benefit is huge. These standards will mean that emission rates from oxides of nitrogen and particulates in new medium to heavy duty trucks will be
. 40 per cent and 70 per cent lower respectively after 2002; and
. 50 per cent and 90 per cent lower respectively after 2006
than they are in vehicles meeting current standards.

Madam President, suggestions have been made in the debate in the House on this bill that the emission standards were going to be put in place anyway. This is incorrect. The standards agreed with the Democrats go beyond what was already proposed.

The National Road Transport Commission, the body responsible for implementing the new standards and recognised by the Opposition as the authority on this subject, has confirmed this package exceeds significantly what was being contemplated.

It does this in three respects; firstly, it accelerates the implementation of Euro 3 standards for diesel vehicles; secondly, it provides for the introduction of Euro 4 standards for dieselâa move not previously contemplated; and thirdly, it delivers cleaner diesel fuel which had not previously been envisaged, which allows these standards and the benefits they offer to deliver much sooner.

Madam President, there has also been some acrimonious debate over carbon dioxide and related Greenhouse gas emissions, with the suggestion that greenhouse gas emissions will increase as a result of this package.

We need to get this issue straight. Greenhouse gas emissions are a serious matter; one which the government intends to address seriously. But expecting the tax package to solve such an issue is nonsense.
Greenhouse gases emitted by the transport sector continue to grow for a reasonâthe reason is that the economy continues to grow, and transport grows with it.

Moreover, there is nothing written in stone or derived from logic that says transport emissions must not rise. For Australia, the question must be what is the least-cost adjustment to reach the Kyoto Convention target, not simply transferring that target to each sector. Clearly, taxing our transport sector more heavily in order to suppress demand for transport is an unacceptable option, unless we are also attempting to suppress overall economic growth.
As a nation, we need to recognise diesel is our main heavy transport fuel.

The solution to lower emissions growth in transport lies with improved engine efficiency, use of Intelligent Transport Systems, better intermodal transfer efficiency, higher public transport efficiency and with better land use planning.
It is not affected in any substantial way by the price of fuel.

The price of fuel has been increased by taxation very significantly in Australia over many years, with not much impact on growth in demand for its use. It is relative pricing that will matter, not the absolute level, as this bill itself demonstrates with its plan to maintain the differentials between fuels.

Under a high fuel tax regime, all that will change is the cost of doing business in Australia. And, for transport-dependent communities in regional Australia, that's not the soft option that it is for some city-based think tanks.
Madam President

We also intend that a further bill, putting in place the administrative arrangements, including the compliance mechanisms needed to support this bill, will be introduced by the government in the Spring Sittings in consultation with the Australian Democrats.

We will be seeking passage of the Administration bill prior to Christmas, in order that industry can develop record-keeping arrangements and plan with confidence for the introduction of the grants scheme on 1 July next year.

The administrative arrangements will be developed by the Australian Taxation Office in consultation with Australian National Audit Office and its views will be factored into the compliance and audit procedures.

The Opposition is trying to run a scare campaign on the question of how this scheme will be administered. In one breath it warns transport operators that they face onerous and intrusive compliance requirements. In the next breath it paints this as a scheme wide open to rorting. It is wrong on both counts.
The government will develop a robust risk management strategy that limits the scope for abuse, but also keeps record-keeping requirements as simple as possible.

Madam President, it is the government's intention that the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grant Scheme and the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme will sunset in mid-2002, and be replaced with an Energy Grants (Credits) Scheme.
The future Energy Grants Scheme will maintain benefits that are equivalent to those available under the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Credit Scheme and the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme.

Very importantly, it is the government's intention that the Energy Grants Scheme will also provide active encouragement for the move to the use of cleaner fuels by measures additional to those available under the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme.
The detail of the Energy Grants Scheme will be developed jointly by the government and the Australian Democrats and introduced through a jointly sponsored bill.

Madam President, this bill is being introduced in a highly charged atmosphere, where emotion may cloud reason. However, there is every reason for all Senators to support itâbecause lower transport costs benefit all Australians; and because of the significant improvements to emission standards inherent in it.
This bill makes a substantial contribution to the case for tax reformâfor without tax reform, the funding required to support it would simply not be available.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
CUSTOMS AND EXCISE AMENDMENT (DIESEL FUEL REBATE SCHEME) BILL 1999

The Customs and Excise Amendment (Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme) Bill 1999 implements changes to the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme agreed with the Australian Democrats as part of the package of environmental measures that will now accompany the introduction of the new tax system on 1 July 2000.

The broad details of the environmental package in so far as it applies to the use of diesel and alternative fuels has been covered in the second reading speech introducing the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Bill 1999, as have the broad details of changes to the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme.
The main features of the Customs and Excise Amendment (Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme) Bill 1999 are as follows:
It introduces a 100 per cent rebate for all diesel used by registered businesses in rail transport and in the marine industry.
It provides for the rebates available for diesel to also be made available to qualifying users of like fuels such as light fuel oil and bunker fuel. These like fuels will be prescribed.
The full rebate will be extended to existing qualifying users, including agriculture, fishing and mining, as well as private residences, bush and other nursing homes, hospitals and aged persons home.

This means that the government intends to rebate all the excise paid on diesel and like fuels for use in primary production, and all currently qualifying mining uses. Currently they do not receive a full rebate. Forestry will continue to have access to the rebate in the proportion it currently receives.

The Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme will sunset on 30 June 2002 and benefits equivalent to those available under it will be grandfathered into the new Energy Grants (Credits) Scheme that will come into effect on 1 July 2002.
Madam President
Those off-road businesses that receive rebates under this scheme can be assured that the government will ensure these benefits are not diminished under the new Energy Grants Scheme.
I commend this bill to the Senate.

APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1999-2000
The purpose of this bill is to appropriate the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the expenses of the Parliamentary Departments for the year ending 30 June 2000.
The total amount sought is $161.5 million. Details of the proposed appropriations are set out in the Schedule to the bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1999-2000

It is with great pleasure that I introduce Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1999-2000, which, together with Appropriation Bill (No.2), is one of the principal pieces of legislation underpinning the first budget of the second term of coalition government.

Appropriation Bill (No. 1) provides authority for meeting expenses on the ordinary annual services of government. The program of the government, to which the provisions in this bill relate, was outlined in the Treasurer's budget Speech, on 11 May.
This bill seeks appropriations of the Consolidated Revenue Fund in 1999-2000 totalling $36,219 million.
Details of the proposed expenditure are set out in the Schedule to the bill, the main features of which were outlined in the Treasurer's budget Speech.
This is an historic occasion for the Parliament.
It is the first time on which the Commonwealth's budget has been presented on the basis of accrual accounting principles.
The move to accruals, which is consistent with the recommendation of the National Committee of Audit, complements and extends the government's accountability under the Charter of budget Honesty.

As noted by my colleague, the Treasurer, the move to accruals means that, for the first time, the budget will contain financial statements for the Commonwealth general government sector for 1998-99, the budget and forward estimates years, including:
. an Operating Statement;
. Statement of Assets and Liabilities;
. Cash Flow Statement; and
. Capital Expenditure Statement.

This means that Parliament, and the community at large, will have comprehensive information on the financial performance of the government consistent with the information disclosed in company annual reports.
This information will be complemented by the inclusion in the Portfolio Budget Statements of full financial statements for all Commonwealth agencies.

In providing estimates in this way, the Commonwealth is moving ahead of the general practice in the private sector where budgets are rarely, if ever, released to shareholders and certainly not for a five year time period.
Under the accrual framework, the focus in the government's Appropriation bills is on:
. achieving agency outcomes, rather than the current input focus; and
. funding for the full price of agency outputs or administered expenses estimated to be in curred, rather than merely estimates of cash payments to be made.
Taken together, these changes disclose to the Parliament the full costs of the government's activities and allow a greater focus on performance of agencies.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1999-2000
Appropriation Bill (No.2) provides for the revenues for agencies to meet:
. expenses in relation to grants to the States under section 96 of the Constitution and for payments to the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory;
. administered expenses on new outcomes; and
. equity injections and loans to agencies as well as administered capital funding.

As part of the transition to accruals, any carryovers from 1998-99 associated with the former running costs system governing Commonwealth departments and agencies are being appropriated in bill 2 as an equity injection.
This bill seeks appropriations of the Consolidated Revenue Fund in 1999-2000 totalling $5950 million.
Details of the proposed appropriations are set out in Schedule 2 to the bill, the main features of which were outlined in the treasurer's budget.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
