subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 24 June and 22 June, on motions by Senator Ian Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to speak on the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) Bill 1999 and the three related bills. I rise to speak a bit earlier than I planned but I am glad to see we are making good progress. First of all I want to indicate at the outset that the Labor opposition supports the thrust of the major bill in that it seeks to consolidate 12 existing family payments into two and to simplify two child-care payments by creating one single regime. Labor supports those measures as being a step in the right direction in terms of simplifying it and making it more understandable for Australian families to access social security payments.

speech.para: I remember lobbying the then Labor social security minister about that issue some years ago. I know he was committed to a similar process of finding a way to make things more simplified but of course the difficulty always with those sorts of processes is to make sure that, in going for simplicity over complexity, you do no erode the very important basis on which a number of those payments were erected; that is, to reflect the needs of different types of families and their different types of problems. We have a very diverse and complex set of families with a diverse and complex set of needs and so, while I think we all support the need for simplicity, transparency and the least complicated system possible, clearly we also want the system to reflect and accommodate those different needs. That is always a task and a challenge, one that has bipartisan support as we try and work our way through these sorts of issues.

So, while simplification is laudable, the test will be whether or not we meet the needs of all Australian families and move into a more simplified and hopefully more transparent social system. I know one of the concerns always in this area is making sure that families get their entitlements. There has been a whole range of measures over the years, introduced by both sides of politics, that have not been as successful as they should have been because people have not been able to work out that they are entitled to them or how to access them, so that will be one of the tests for this measure. So, as I say, we do support the general thrust and we hope that, as well as rationalising the system, there are rational outcomes as well.

I do want to say that it is unfortunate that these measures have been linked to the goods and services tax debate. The Labor Party's fundamental proposition is that the goods and services tax is a regressive measure that will impact unfairly and harshly on families. To have this measure tied up with the goods and services tax legislation, from our point of view is unfortunate and tends to prevent us from focusing properly on the measures contained in these bills. But, if nothing else, I am a realist. We have had the debate on the GST and, while there are other measures to go, it is quite clear that this parliament is going to carry those bills.

I am pleased to say that these bills will be far more beneficial and will make some contribution to ameliorating the worst impacts of the GST, but they will not provide the sort of protection that I believe is necessary for Australian families, because the GST will be regressive in its impact. It will impact on families more harshly than the current taxation regime, it will have a disproportionate impact on low income families, and it will have a disproportionate impact on people like disability pensioners and others who rely a great deal on services which currently are not taxed. So, while we are prepared to support this measure, its linkage with the GST is highly unfortunate and means that it has not had the sort of attention that the measure deserved. But, as I say, we are prepared to take a rational view of these things and, because we think it is generally a beneficial measure, we will be supporting the bill.

I want to address a couple of other measures in the related bills. As a result of the agreement between the government and the majority of Democrat senators, we have not really had proper time to look at the consequential bills that are included in this package. I have a couple of concerns which are the subject of amendments I will be moving in the committee stage, but I have a more general concern that the speed with which these bills have been introducedâpushed through the House of Representatives and then into the Senate without any committee inquiry process or any great public consultationâis a very poor process and leaves me concerned that there may well be aspects of these related bills that have not received the scrutiny that they need and that we will not make properly informed judgments on these bills.

I know there is always a bit of time pressure, but these bills have been introduced at very short notice and with very scant consideration. I think we would all agree that in terms of process that is not desirable, and so I have put a caveat on my support for some of the measures in these bills because I do not think either the parliament or the community more generally have had a chance to get on top of some of the issues. As they go to questions of administration, they are quite complex and there are potential problems that have not been considered, so I have some concern about that.

Of particular concern is the approach taken in these bills in relation to child-care matters. When we were briefed by the minister's staff on the family assistance package as it related to child care, we were told that the details of the child-care issues at stake in the new regimeâthe questions of how people would be paid, who would be a qualified carer and all those sorts of thingsâwould all be contained in the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) Bill 1999 . In the last couple of days I have been able to have a look at the bills, and I have found that the child-care issues have not been included. Today I received the Library's Bills Digests on these bills. It quite rightly makes the same pointâthat the treatment of child-care regulation or child-care arrangements under these bills is quite different. I quote the Library's Bills Digests:

Rather than set out the requirements in the bill concerning claims, determinations and payments, new division 4 basically provides for the making of regulations about how individuals in approved child-care services can become entitled to have payments of child-care benefit made and how such payments are to be made.

So, rather than the bill containing, as we were assured, the details of the regime in terms of child care, it has been treated quite differently from the approach in the more general social security matters, and the matters will all have to be dealt with by way of regulation. I know many of those will be disallowable instruments, and the parliament will have the opportunity to consider those regulations in due course, but I do think that that is not a proper way to go. It is a case of giving too much authority and too much content in regulations and not enough in the primary legislation.

There has always been a tendency or a temptation on behalf of government to adopt that sort of approach because it does mean that parliament has less scrutiny of the detail and less ability to influence the detail. I am sure that was not the case on this occasionâmaybe it was the speed with which things were doneâbut it does leave the parliament with less ability to properly scrutinise and determine how those arrangements are put in place.

While I have received assurances from the government about the new regime that there will be very little change to the current regime that is in place, I do have some concerns about this method. I put the government on notice that the Labor opposition will scrutinise those regulations very carefully and will not hesitate to use the power to block those regulations if they are not in accordance with both proper practice and the assurances given to us. I am sure the Democrats will also take a fairly critical look at them because we are not getting the opportunity on this occasion to examine them because of the way this has been structured. As I say, I hope there is nothing more sinister or devious involved in this approach.

As the opposition child-care spokesperson, I will be taking a very keen interest to make sure that the industry receives reassurance about the concerns that it has about some of the options the government was considering. The government has given commitments on a number of those matters, such as payment in arrears rather than in advance and a couple of other issues. I do want to note that, while the government has lived up to its election commitment to provide that parents should be able to choose to be paid directly, I think the reality of the bill's measures is that the current system will stay in place for the majority of families. For people to take the annual payment option, I think they would need to be very high income earners; otherwise they would not be able to carry the cost of their child care each week.

While I am sure the government will be keen to claim that this measure meets its election commitments, I think good sense has prevailed and most families will continue to operate under the regime currently in place. That will provide much more security to child-care providers who, I think, felt very threatened by the move to an alternative regime, because they thought that they could end up with substantial bad debt problems. As we all know, bad debt is a constant threat to small businesses at the best of times. Child-care centres have some problems in that area, but I think they were most concerned that that would be exacerbated. So I am pleased that the regime in place within this legislative framework will prevent that becoming a more significant problem for the sector.

The other thing to note about the level of child-care assistance is that, while the extra assistance for child care will be welcomed, it does not apply until July 2000. I think, then, it will basically go only part way to compensating for the cap that the government has imposed on child-care assistance for the last two years and does nothing to address the real structural issues at stake in the child-care industry in this country. The affordability problem is driving closure of centres and forcing families to remove children from formal child care. I am afraid the beneficial measures contained in this bill will come too late to halt that process and, I think, come too late for many families in terms of them accessing the formal child-care sector. Any assistance will obviously help, but I do not think it will be enough. It will be very much a case of too little, too late. When combined with the government's other measures of reducing funding for child care and the other structural changes made by this government over the last couple of years, I think we will continue to see enormous pressure on families' capacity to afford child care and enormous stress on the industry's ability to cope, given that significant drop in demand.

But with those comments, I wish to reiterate that we will be supporting the bills. I have circulated a couple of amendments to the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) Bill 1999 , and I see that Senator Bartlett has moved what I suspect are similar amendmentsâat least in one respect. I hope those are supported, because they raise very serious issues about people's access to review of decisions. I will address those concerns in the committee stage.

talk.start.para: âThe Senate is debating in the second reading stage the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) Bill 1999 , the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Consequential and Related Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999 , the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Consequential and Related Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1999 and A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) Bill 1999 . This legislation contains a number of improvements to family assistance measures to lighten the burden placed on many families by the government's youth allowance package last year and, as the previous speaker indicated, has been linked to the overall package of changes as part of the A New Tax System package.

speech.para: The Democrats certainly support measures which give greater financial support to families and measures that raise the income test threshold to a more realistic rate and address the poverty trap caused by the current 50 per cent taper rate. The impact of poverty traps under existing legislation is certainly one of the biggest disincentive measures, and the Democrats welcome the moves in this legislation to mitigate that, as we did other measures relating to pensions. We certainly hope that the government does consider acting in the future in the area that I believe is perhaps the one most in need of action, which is the poverty trap or taper rate applying to unem ployed people. We certainly welcome this improvement in the taper rate contained in this legislation.

I would like to put on the record the Democrats' continuing concerns with definitions of age of independence. Defining the age of independence for a student as 25 and for a young unemployed person as 21 is inconsistent with definitions of adulthood and independence in other legislation and perpetrates an irrational view of young people's circumstances and real responsibilities. Senator Harradine, as senators would be aware, in debates over the youth allowance legislation last year put on record his concerns at the pressure that would be put on lower and middle income earners who would be hit harder because they face the financial burden of supporting young adult children up to the age of 21 for young unemployed and up to 25 years old for students. The Democrats are still of the belief that 18 should be the recognised age of independence, whether people are unemployed or students. It provides a more accurate reflection of the realities of society and also the reality of financial burdens that young adults face.

This legislation provides some relief for families who were impacted by the youth allowance measures implemented last year. At that time, the government gave the following undertaking to Senator Harradine with respect to support for those families. They assured Senator Harradine that:

. . . in restructuring the Australian taxation system, to which this government is committed, the government will give further recognition and help to Australian parents concerning their responsibilities in . . . raising sons and daughters, Australia's future taxpayers.

While this concern was not initially honoured by the government, this bill finally makes good that commitment by increasing the family tax benefit part A to $50 per fortnight and by increasing eligibility for it. Certain young persons aged 21 to 25 who are engaged in full-time study and young unemployed persons aged 18 to 25 will be eligible for the family tax benefit part A. Where they would attract a higher rate of income support as a family tax benefit child than they would as a youth allowance recipient, they will be able to opt for the former, with the payments going to an adult. This measure involves an additional $50 million in expenditure per year by the government, and that will address some of the financial hardships suffered since the implementation of the youth allowance last year.

Of course, there is still some way to go in this area. I note concerns raised within the welfare sector that these amendments will benefit higher income families while less relief will be afforded families where the young person is eligible for a higher rate of youth allowance. These are measures that the Democrats believe do need ongoing attention; however, we welcome the financial relief contained in this bill as an important first step to redressing some of the other anomalies contained in the provision of family and youth income support. There are some significant advances here and, as always when advances occur, the Democrats are quite happy to acknowledge them and support them, as we will do. As Senator Evans indicated, there are a couple of areas where there are some amendments, which we will address in the committee stage, and I will outline my rationale for those at the time. In closing, Madam Acting Deputy President, I would like to check whether there any other speakers on this bill present in the chamber.

talk.start.para: âIt appears not.

âIn which case, I could wax lyrical for another five minutes or we could have an early dinner break; I thought I would spare you the trauma and let you have dinner four minutes earlier. I do have one sentence left. Whilst it is important that the measures in this bill help address the financial needs of familiesâand the Democrats welcome thoseâI would like to emphasise that one of the growing areas of poverty in society is that of young single people. The needs of single people is an area of society which I think, perhaps in the rush to try to address the very real financial needs of families, has been a bit obscured by that. It certainly does appear from recent research that young single people are often amongst the biggest growing group in society in terms of poverty levels, and it is an area that I think we do need to pay more attention to when we are looking at income support and other forms of financial assistance and legislation of that type. So I would like to certainly flag the Democrats' interest in ensuring that that group in society is not forgotten. That is not to say, of course, that families are not important or that they do not have extra financial burdens; we are pleased that this legislation does go a long way towards addressing some of those burdens. It is legislation that the Democrats support.

A NEW TAX SYSTEM (FAMILY ASSISTANCE) (ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1999
The bill.

talk.start.para: âMr Chairman, I seek your guidance as we do not have an amendment sheet circulated for the family assistance administration bill.
âYes. It is appropriate now to move those amendments to the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) Bill 1999 , having dealt with the first two.
âI am just clarifying that we are in committee on the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) Bill, are we?
âThat is correct.
âThere are a few amendments here. I seek leave to move the first two together.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: (1) Heading to clause 107, page 90 (line 21), omit "time limits and" .
(2) Clause 107, page 9 (line 22) to page 91 (line 4), omit subsections (1), (2) and (3).

These amendments deal the section of the legislation to do with review applications and time limits that are set on that; these are internal reviews rather than appeals to the SSAT. I did have brief discussions with the minister's office today about this and the subsequent amendment, which has also been circulated and also contained in Senator Evans's circulated amendments.

The issue this seeks to address is basically the component of the act which, in this case, seeks to limit the amount of time in which people have the ability to appeal a decision. As I understand it, currently the Social Security Act provides that a person can appeal a decision from the original decision maker at any time, although there are some limitations. The person is entitled to back-payment only to the date on which the original decision was made, if their application for review is made within three months of receiving the written decision.

As I think Senator Evans indicated in his speech in the second reading debate, this was part of a package of legislation linked in with a large number of tax bills. From the Democrats' perspective, we have not really had adequate time, given our limited resources and focus, to examine the desirability or otherwise of this measure. I know the government does have some arguments as to why it is a good idea. However, if it is as good an idea as the government thinks, it can spend the intervening couple months convincing either us or the ALP of that when we get to the Social Security (Administration) Bill 1999 later in the year. I am certainly quite willing to be open to arguments and revisit the issue then, if there are suitable arguments for proceeding down this path. At the moment I am a bit sceptical about the desirability of that and, for that reason, at this stage at any rate I have moved these amendments to remove those sections from the legislation.

talk.start.para: âSenator Bartlett, you indicated that you were moving two amendments initially. We have three amendments listed on the running sheet. Could you just clarify which two you have just spoken on.
âThey are amendments Nos 1 and 2. Amendment No. 3 is in opposition to a clause.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI see that Senator Evans is also wanting to address this issue. I know that he has an amendment which would be following on or in lieu of this. I take up briefly the challenge put out by Senator Bartlett. If you are going to be considering your position in the longer term, the Social Security (Administration) Bill 1999 comes before us later in the year and it would be worth while having on the record why the government is not happy with the amend ments being proposed by both the Democrats and the opposition.

speech.para: Section 107 establishes a 52-week time limit following the notification of a decision within which an application for review of a decision must be lodged. Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, a greatly respected former social security minister whose proposal this is, suggested that the administration of a mass decision making system requires some finality in dealing with applicants and that a period of 12 months would be appropriate for a person to seek a review of a departmental officer's decision. This provision will ensure that the family assistance review and appeals system compares more consistently with other systems in which time limits apply. For example, the Refugee Review Tribunal and Migration Review Tribunal both allow a total of 35 days for application for review by the tribunal of a decision made in Australia. There is no internal review and they have no special circumstances exemption to the time limits.

The Archives Act permits destruction of a file 12 months after a customer ceases to receive payment, and it is no advantage to have to deal with a request for review where the papers have been destroyed and there is virtually no other available evidence. In such cases as present, it is common for the AAT not to grant extensions of time. The bill provides a capacity to extend the time limit where there are special circumstances. If you like, Senator Bartlett, I see that as being the necessary fall-back or protection for individuals' rights. I will address your next amendment when you move it.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the Labor opposition, I indicate that we are inclined to support these first two Democrat amendments in much the same sort of frame of mind as Senator Bartlett brought to this issue. The chamber will notice that we did not seek to amend this section ourselves. Our main concern is with the next measure, which was the 28-day limit on appeals to SSAT. But I think the same general concern that I expressed in the second reading debate pervades our approach to all of thisâthat there has not been a great deal of consideration of what has been in the administration bills.

speech.para: There is a bit of nervousness on our part that there has not been proper consideration of the implications of some of these measures. From a quick chat I have had with the opposition spokesman on social security, Mr Wayne Swan, while he was not necessarily inclined to oppose, our general approach is to be a bit cautious about some of these proposals till we are able to discuss what they mean in more detail with those who represent people who could be adversely affected.

On balance, while our main concern is with the next section, which we will be opposing, we are inclined to support the Democrat amendments on the same basis that we think there needs to be a bit more light and air applied to these measures. They are part of an approach to social security that will be dealt with more fundamentally, I gather, in a bill coming before us a bit later. In the short term, we are inclined to err on the side of caution. For that reason, we will be supporting these two Democrat amendments.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI respond briefly to Senator Evans. I respect the concerns of the Democrats and the opposition about these measures in the legislation. I just want to make it quite clear that this is the way the government is intending to take the entire social security systemâretaining a fair system, which it is, but making it slightly more efficient without removing people's rights. As I mentioned to Senator Bartlett, there would still be the opportunity for people to get the time limit extended where there are special circumstances. So the government is very ready to have other parties have a look at this over the break and be ready to come back after having given the issue greater thought. I urge you, though, to come on board and support it when it appears again in the Social Security (Administration) Bill 1999 .

speech.para: There were a number of things that needed attention. Dame Margaret, as a former social security minister, is widely respected for how well and widely she consulted prior to prepar ing her report on the system. It was not done lightly and it was not done in any mode of slash and burn; it was trying to be fair to the taxpayer and fair to the person needing assistance. With that encouragement to spend the breakâ

talk.start.para: âAfter a week's holiday.
âYou cannot have a week's holiday. With that encouragement to spend the break in worthy pursuit of an even better social security review system, I do urge that you give attention to the matter.
âThe question is that amendments Nos 1 and 2 moved by Senator Bartlett be agreed to.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: âWe intend to oppose clause in the following terms:

speech.para: (3) Clause 112, page 94 (lines 1 to 7), TO BE OPPOSED .

As indicated, the Democrats wish to oppose clause 112 of this legislationâfor similar sorts of reasons. This one limiting appeals to the SSAT to only 28 days is particularly problematic. As I said previously, we are willing to examine it in more detail over the longer period of time. Partly in response to some of the minister's previous comments, it would be preferable to look at all of the issues that were raised in the Guilfoyle report as a group rather than in a piecemeal way, with some aspects of it coming in here and some aspects coming in other legislation. A lot of different proposals have been put forward there, and I think they need to be looked at in detail. That is not a reflection on their appropriateness or notâI am sure there are lots of good ideas in there.

With something as complex as a social security act, if measures are introduced that do have unforeseen effects it does tend to mean that people at the bottom end of the scale are negatively affected. From the Democrats' perspective, it is something we are keen to examine in detail to make sure that what we are doing is not going to unfairly impact on the less well-off. For that reason, particularly in this area, the Democrats would be keen to remove this section from the bill at this stage, examine it more fully and the rationale behind it when we get to later legislation and do that as a whole. That is a more appropriate way to go and certainly what we would prefer to do.

talk.start.para: âThe Labor opposition have a similar amendment to that of the Democrats, which is to oppose clause 112. Our opposition is based on the short consultation time we have been able to have and the fact that some concerns have been raised by people who represent people in appeals before the Social Security Appeals Tribunal as to the process suggested. We are concerned that the effect of the limit proposed by the government is to effectively cut off the right of appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and then the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, because one flows from the other. As Senator Bartlett has said, we anticipated these measures being part of the Social Security (Administration) Bill 1999 , to be dealt with when we considered that bill. We are most concerned that they do not go through the chamber today without the concerns being raised and, hopefully, that we do not end up with such a precedent being included.

speech.para: We are not at all convinced that the measure is necessary. I will be interested to hear what the minister has to say, but our view is that this has the potential to impact on those who are most vulnerable in our community because of their lack of language skills, their non-English speaking background or other difficulties they might have, such as intellectual disabilities. These people are the ones less likely to be able to cope with the system and to be able necessarily to exercise their rights within that time frame. They may well be in a position of crisis when they have to look to exercise those rights. There are a range of reasons why people might well be at that time homeless, recently unemployed or going through a family crisis and who are not necessarily in a position to fully understand or advocate their own rights within a 28-day time limit. The Labor Party is most concerned that that might have an impact on their ability to exercise their rights. We do not think that would be a desirable outcome.

It has also been put to us that in some cases we might see an increase in the number of appeals as welfare rights advocates encourage people to make appeals to protect their rights if they are uncertain about the final outcome of their overall situation. I know the minister has already referred in a previous debate to the question of special circumstances, but we are concerned how that provision might be applied, in the sense that it is another hurdle for people to get over to prove that their circumstances are somehow special.

We do not see the justification for the 28-day time limit. We think that in the regime the government is putting in place people have the real potential to be disadvantaged and that the special circumstances test may provide a hurdle that is too high for people genuinely in need of exercising those appeal rights. My major concern is that those who are least able to look after themselves and who are most vulnerable will be those for whom the rules will not work. Clearly, we want a social security system that allows all those people to access their full rights. For those reasons we think it would be inappropriate to include the 28-day time limit and we will be opposing it.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI thank senators for their contribution to this aspect of the legislation. I do think that perhaps their fears are unfounded. Clause 112 establishes a 28-day time limit following the notification of a decision for application to the SSAT for review. Dame Margaret pointed out that in most jurisdictions there is some period during which an appeal against a decision may be lodged. That of itself is not an untoward provision.

speech.para: This provision sets a time for lodging an appeal that is consistent with that which currently exists under the Social Security Act for lodgment to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It has not been seen to be an unfair time limit for appeals to the AAT. I do not understand why it could be seen as being an unfair time limit for application to the SSAT for a review. By the time we get to that stage in the system, the customer will have received a letter from an authorised review officer explaining the adverse decision in plain English and, accompanying the letter, an application for appeal to the SSAT and information on how to lodge an appeal. With this level of information and assistance, I do not think it is unreasonable for a customer to decide to lodge an appeal within 28 days.

Having said thatâand Senator Evans has just emphasised the issue of special circumstancesâcapacity is provided in the bill for the period of appeal to be extended where there are special circumstances. I would remind senators that Centrelink and the social security system have for many years been accustomed to dealing with people who are particularly vulnerable. It may be people with mental illness or intellectual incapacity or who are perhaps addicted to alcohol or drugs and are therefore not well able to represent their own interests. The need to protect the people for whom the special circumstances provision is provided is well understood by both the Department of Family and Community Services and Centrelink. I believe that in the circumstances the time limit is not unfair, but even if people had some vulnerability which precluded them from getting in application in that 28 days, the special circumstances provision would be a safety net to protect the most vulnerable.

talk.start.para: âIn brief response to that, from my point of view, on behalf of the Democrats, before agreeing to such a time limitâwhich on the face of it seems a fairly short period of time in my experienceâI would certainly like to be able to examine the reality of the current situation in a bit more detail: how long people currently take to appeal the SSAT, and what percentage of people take longer than 28 days and what the reasons might be in those circumstances. Certainly, there is a category here of special circumstances that gives some flexibility, but I am concerned that that is a little bit arbitrary. I realise that you need to have some space for flexibility in any area of administrative law but, in something that is dealing with people's basic welfare and ability to get some basic income support, I think arbitrariness is a bit of a dangerous component to have too much of. So that does give me some concern.

speech.para: I would again indicate to the minister that the Democrats and I am sure the Australian Labor Partyâreasonable folks that they areâare quite willing to examine this and be convinced, once we have had the opportunity to look at it in a bit more detail. The Democrats, as the government and indeed the nation as a whole are well aware, are quite willing to cooperate with the government on the odd occasion. I am sure that we can extend that cooperativeness to an area such as this, if the arguments are good enough, but certainly I am also keen to ensure that we have enough time. I do not see it as being a major problem to the administration of government or the finances of the nation for us to consider this at a bit more length and re-include this as part of the overall system when we do the Social Security (Administration) Bill 1999, if enough of the Senate have been convinced that that is the way to go.

I do think that particularly with this bill, certainly on the surface, that a 28-day limit seems to be quite a short period of time in which to enable people to appeal. Whilst there is the special circumstances exemption, it is not particularly clearly defined and leaves some room for arbitrariness, which again would be of concern to the Democrats. So I would indicate that we would press this issue, at this point in time, to seek to remove this clause from the bill. Once we have looked at it more closely over the next couple of months, we might be persuaded to go down the path that the government is suggesting across the board in the Social Security Act.

talk.start.para: âThe question is that clause 112 stand as printed.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the opposition, I move:

speech.para: Clause 126, page 103 (lines 2 to 6), omit subclause (1), substitute:
(1) The Executive Director may direct that a hearing be conducted without oral submissions from those parties that may make oral submissions if:
(a) the Executive Director considers that the review hearing could be determined fairly on the basis of written submissions by all the parties to the review; and
(b) all parties to the review consent to the hearing being conducted without oral submissions.

This amendment to clause 126 deals with the issue of the right of a party to make oral submissions to a Social Security Appeals Tribunal review. The government is proposing a new section which codifies the powers of the executive director and effectively allows for that person, on certain occasions and within certain guidelines, to rule that all social security appeal matters are heard by way of written submission and not orally. The amendment seeks to insert the option of all parties needing to consent to the matter being conducted without oral submissions.

We are concerned that this might create a dangerous precedent whereby parties are not allowed to make oral submissions in support of their claims by a decision of the executive director. I am sure the minister will say there are appropriate guidelines and restrictions on that power, but we are concerned that parties may not have that opportunity. That may well be the best way for them to put forward their case and, if they are restricted from articulating their case in this way, that may limit their right to a fair hearing and to seek the benefits of a favourable decision from the tribunal.

Again, this is one of these measures that I understand will be in the Social Security (Administration) Bill 1999, which will come before the parliament again in August. It may well be that there is some way of making progress on this measure other than this, but at this stage we are very concerned that the government's policy direction would not necessarily allow people the right to make oral submissions. We think the amendment we are moving, which basically requires the consent of all the parties to obviate that requirement to have oral hearings, is a better approach. I urge the Senate to support that amendment.

talk.start.para: âI want to speak briefly on this and to support strongly the proposition put by Senator Chris Evans, because this whole issue has a long history. It is interesting that Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has been mentioned here tonight. I was a member of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal in the days when she was the minister. There was a big debate about oral hearings as opposed to written submissions. It is interesting to note that, in those days, one of the strongest supporters of oral hearings was Senator Mal Colston.

speech.para: In that debate, one of the issues was that a very small percentage of appellants' appeals was upheld, particularly by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal in Brisbane. I believed, as others did at the time, that one of the reasons was that people were discouraged from making appearances and giving oral evidence. I remember wading through acres of paper, and often the people who were appealing were not aware of the detrimental reports which were given from time to time in writing and which were then used by the tribunal against the appeal. I often felt that if only people could appear and give oral evidence, then the determination would have gone the other way.

When there was a review by the minister of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal's operation, I spoke strongly about this. It is interesting that, a little later on, I was invited to step down from the appeals tribunal. At the time I was strongly supported by Senator George Georges, who took up the case. But that is all history; you do not really want to know about that.

What I do want to underline is that I believe this measure is important. It is important to preserve the right of people to an oral hearing and that that right will not simply fall over because of a decision by the executive director without people being aware of their rights and agreeing to the abrogation of their right to an oral hearing. The amendment does that. It determines that there should be consent, and if there is consent then the determination can be made on the basis of written submissions, but there should be some safeguard to that. Because of that debate of some years ago and how important it was for people to exercise the right to an oral hearing, I would urge the Senate to support the Labor amendment.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âMr Chairman, I was interested in that history. When I first came into the Senate, it was George Georges that opened my eyes to the ALP treatment of one of its own when he voted against the party. I was quite shocked. But that is history, as Senator Woodley said.

speech.para: I draw this to the Senate's attention: the bill actually provides that the executive director `may direct' a hearing `without oral submissions', if the executive director considers the review hearing `could be determined fairly on the basis of written submissions'. The word is `may', not `have to' or `compelled to'; he or she may direct it, if he or she considers that the hearing `could be determined fairly on the basis of written submissions'.

Clause 126 goes on to say in part (4), subsection 1: `The tribunal may, after considering those written submissions . . . ' So if the director says that it would be fair to all the parties to go on the written papers to the SSAT, the SSAT, after reading the submissions, can still say, `We believe that the parties should be permitted to make oral submissions.' I am sure Senator Woodley would recognise that that does put in that balance what you are concerned aboutâthat is, of people being excluded from being heard. I understand that concern, but I think subsection (1) and subsection (4) of clause 126 do protect and look after the concerns that Senator Woodley was referring to.

In addition, I am concerned at the drafting of the ALP amendment. I do not know whether Senator Evans has had a really hard look at the drafting. To me it looks a bit nonsensical. I will demonstrate why. The ALP's second amendment is:
Clause 126, page 103, (lines 2 to 6), omit subclause (1), substitute:
(1) The Executive Director may directâ
there it is, `may', but he or she directsâ
that a hearing be conducted without oral submissions . . . if . . .
et cetera. Part (b) says:
. . . all parties to the review consent to the hearing being conducted without oral submissions.

So, on the one hand, the executive director is being given the powerâthe discretion, if you like to put it that way, because it is `may' directâto direct. That is what subsection (1) says: `may direct'. Then in 1 (b), it says if:
. . . all parties to the review consent to the hearing being conducted without oral submissions.

So on the one hand he has the power to direct and on the other hand it has to be with the consent of all the parties. So what is direction if it cannot be exercised without the consent of all the parties? I think somebody took their mind out of gear between the drafting of the second line and the last line. From that point of view, I do not think your amendment is a very good one. Quite apart from whatever you were trying to achieve, the drafting is not all that crash-hot.

I will not delay the Senate any longer. For both those reasonsâthat there is sufficient protection within the government's legislation and that the ALP's attempt to amend it is not a very satisfactory attemptâI would urge the Senate to oppose the opposition's amendment.

talk.start.para: âI do not want to delay the Senate unduly, but certainly the minister's last point was lost on me. The wording is exactly the same as in the government's bill, except that we say the executive director `may direct' that a hearing be conducted and then we set down the provisos. The first is they have to be satisfied that it can be determined fairly and the second is that they have consulted the parties and gained their consent. It seems to be quite straightforward, but I admit that, unlike the minister, who is one of 19 lawyers on the front bench of the Liberal Party, I am not a lawyer. But it seems to me that the wording is exactly the same as that used in the bill. The direction, though, can only be issued once they have satisfied the two criteria; one of those is getting the consent of the parties. Otherwise, the wording is in exactly the same language as is in the govern ment's bill. Anyway, I do not think we want to delay with an unduly long debate.

speech.para: It seems to me that that objection does not have a great deal of substance. The wording is much the same. What we are inserting is that, before they make that direction, they seek the consent of the parties. Obviously the intent of the thing is to make sure they have that consent rather than exercise that purely on their own view. But I urge the Senate to support the amendment.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chris Evans's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
