subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Appointment of Mr Laurie Foley

talk.start.para: âLast week I advised the Senate of the circumstances that led to the appointment of Mr Laurie Foley to the position of Assistant Director, Air Safety Compliance, with the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. Mr Foley, as a CASA board member, had participated in the development and approval of a new management structure for the authority. That process created a number of new senior positions. Mr Foley participated in the selection of a recruitment agency to assist CASA in filling those positions. He was also a candidate for one of those positions, but he did not declare an interest.

speech.para: As I told the Senate last week, at a board meeting on 15 May the process to be followed in interviewing candidates for these jobs and the role of the board in that process were discussed. The process was to involve a number of panels with a member of the board sitting on each panel. Mr Foley told the board he was not able to participate in that process but did not advise his fellow board members as to why he was unavailable.

In fact, Mr Foley did not advise the Chairman, Mr Smith, that he was a candidate for the position of Assistant Director, Air Safety Compliance, until 4 June. That was several months after he had discussions with Spencer Stuart about a possible jobâSpencer Stuart being the headhunter consultant being used to fill the vacant positions. It was one month after he had met with the CASA recruitment firm to discuss his candidacy and one monthâless two daysâafter he told Spencer Stuart he was an applicant for the position of Assistant Director, Air Safety Compliance. It was nearly three weeks after he had declined to participate in the staff selection process but had omitted to tell anyone he was a candidate in that process. Mr Foley then waited a further three weeks before he formally tendered his resignation to the minister.

This process is in sharp contrast to the Auditor-General's corporate code of conduct. The Auditor-General said the behaviour of the board affects the integrity, ethics, values and other aspects of corporate culture. What sort of integrity, what sorts of ethics and what sorts of values are conveyed to CASA employees by the manner in which Mr Foley conducted himself?

The CASA board has been quick to criticise some staff for being too close to the industry they regulate. Dick Smith and Mr Toller used terms like `mateship' and `cronyism' when talking about their own staff at the February estimates committee hearings. I do not have to ask what CASA staff think of the manner in which Mr Foley was appointed to a job worth at least $150,000 a year. I do not have to ask what they think of the role played by Mr Willoughby, Mr Smith and possibly others in the creation and filling of a senior management position with one of their own. I know what they think of it.

I now wish to advise the Senate of the actual selection process followed that led to the appointment of Mr Foley. Spencer Stuart advertised these positions in the national press on 1 and 2 May last year. They received 61 applications. Five applicants were short-listed and, according to Mr Toller, three candidates were interviewed. Two were interviewed on or before 24 Mayâwhich was a Sundayâand Mr Foley was not interviewed until 1 July. Mr Toller told the committee he interviewed one of the candidates, and possibly both, prior to receiving a report from the recruitment firm. He did not explain why he chose to do the interview prior to getting expert advice from Spencer Stuart. He did say he was asked by Mr Smith to interview one candidate and he did so.

Although Mr Toller alone interviewed the three candidates for the Foley positionâat his initiativeâhe did not look at the original list of applicants or even at an intermediate list. He only received the short list of three candidates. He did, however, see an intermediate list for all of the other positions. I think there were at least three other positions being filled at the same time. The selection panel for the other positions consisted of Mr Toller, a board member, Mr Willoughby and Mr Wheatley from Spencer Stuart.

Despite the fact that Mr Toller had interviewed two of the three candidates for the Foley job on or about 24 May, it was not until 17 Juneâthree weeks laterâthat Mr Willoughby provided the board with a list of all candidates for all positions and summaries of the leading contenders. Mr Foley was not included in that mail-out. As I said, Mr Toller interviewed Mr Foley on 1 July. Mr Foley was advised on 1 Julyâthe same dayâthat he had been successful in his application. That appointment, and Mr Foley's resignation from the CASA board, was announced on 3 July.

Despite earlier advice from Mr Toller that there were only three candidates on the short list for the Foley position, there were in fact five. It is not clear who the other short-listed candidates were or why they were not interviewed. There were also two other candidates for the Foley position. Mr Toller thought they were not on the short list of five but Mr Wheatley and Mr Willoughby interviewed them both on the afternoon of 26 June. One was a senior CASA officer from Darwin and the other a senior CASA officer from Adelaide. Both, before they attended the interviews, sought a clear statement that they were being considered for the job. Neither wanted to spend hours in an aircraftâone was flying from Darwin to Canberraâif they were only going to be used to legitimise the interview process.

But that is exactly what happened. Both candidates flew in for the interview. One was interviewed at 2.30 p.m. and the other at 3 p.m. and that was itâhalf-hour interviews. Mr Toller said the headhunter advised that neither candidate was up to the mark. The committee was told these candidates were interviewed as a result of a decision of the CASA board. I asked whether that decision was minuted. I was assisted at the estimates hearings by Mr Elder, an officer of CASA, who told me that he did not think it was. He said that the decision was possibly taken in a closed or private session. He said:
It would not always be minuted.
Somewhat surprised by that answer, I then asked, `If the board makes a decision, it is a decision, and presumably the board decisions are minuted.' Mr Toller replied:
No, not all decisions. The board makes formal decisions and the board makes informal decisions. All resolutions of the board will be minuted, but informal decisions will not necessarily be minuted.

I then asked what status informal decisions had. I was told that, if they were board decisions and all board members abided by them, they had the power of the boardâwhatever that means. Mr Elder said that, as far as board decisions taken outside the formal process are concerned, if the board wished to have a decision minuted for the formal record they would advise him and he would record it.

The CASA board has a two-tier system of decision making: a formal decision making process that is minuted, and an informal decision making process that is not minuted. This sits very awkwardly with Mr Barrett's rules. Based on the evidence from both Mr Toller and Mr Elder, minutes from CASA board meetings do not accurately record outcomes from meetings; those minutes only record some decisions. Under such a system, how can the board be properly held accountable for decisions it takes if they are not all recorded?

My own recent experience allows me to illustrate this point very simply. On 21 July last year I asked a question on noticeâquestion No. 1248âabout Mr Foley's application for, and appointment to, the position of Assistant Director. An answer to that question was never provided to me through the normal channels. I actually received a copy of the answer via a freedom of information request. Clearly, the answer was held back in the minister's office. The answer that was prepared contained an error. The error was detected by CASA and corrected. Mr Elder, then General Manager, Corporate Relations, wrote to Carol Boughton, Assistant Secretary, Aviation Industry Division of the department, on 13 October.

The first version of the answer stated the recruitment firm Spencer Stuart had approached Mr Foley on 5 June 1998 and that Mr Foley had agreed to be considered for the position on 7 June. Those dates put the contact between Mr Foley and the recruitment firm one day after he told the board of his intention to apply for the job. Mr Elder advised that the dates should read 5 May and 7 Mayâa month before the board was advised of his intention. An ungenerous person might conclude that this answer was designed to deceive. A generous person might conclude that CASA's records were inaccurate or incomplete.

In the estimates hearings Mr Toller was also forced to correct another error in that answer No. 1248. The answer claimed that Mr Toller and Mr Willoughby conducted interviews for the Foley position. As we know, Mr Toller alone conducted those three interviews. The same ungenerous person might see this as another attempt to mislead and the same generous person might conclude there were further inaccuracies or omissions in CASA records. Mr Elder was also forced to write to the committee to correct an answer about the timing of the board meeting at which Mr Willoughby proposed a process to select candidates. The original date was given as 15 April; the new date was 15 May.
On 1 June Mr Toller emailed all staff a memo. The subject was a code of conduct and ethics. In a covering note Mr Toller said:
Research has shown that ethical standards of an organisation impact on staff job satisfaction, commitment to the organisation, turnover and levels of stress.
He said that management is about leading by example. He might also like to send a copy of his code of conduct to the board.

subdebateinfo.title: Valedictory: Thanks
Department of Defence Officers: Estimates Hearings

talk.start.para: âBefore I move to the topic I wish to raise on the adjournment tonight, I would like to thank the Senate for the pleasure and the fellowship it has given me over the years. It has been a very great privilege to serve this chamber and through this chamber to serve the nation. I want to thank sincerely those senators who mentioned me for their words the other night. As we go through life we learn by experience and many views change. One idea that I had when I entered the Senate still remains with me, though, and that is that there are more than enough good men and women in this parliament to form a very able government. The problem is that they are not concentrated in any one party.

speech.para: I would also like to thank all the staff of the parliament for the courtesy and support they have unfailingly shown me over the yearsâthe clerks, the secretariat staff, the attendants and everyone else. Their dedication to this institution is beyond reproach.

The subject I want to raise tonight concerns the performance of some officers in the Department of Defence at the recent Senate estimates hearings. Several points need to be addressed, and they are all serious. The first point relates to the way Defence has handled safety measures in relation to the Collins submarine. I raised a question on this in the previous hearings in relation to the V31 valve incident. It must be emphasised that this is a question, not a statement of fact. This valve is a valve which connects the interior, the bilge of the submarine, to the outside ocean. Naturally it is closed when the submarine has dived. For safety reasons, it is controlled by two systems. Beyond a certain depth a depth sensor, or transducer, prevents the valve being opened, and that system cannot be overridden by human control. At a shallow depth it can be overridden by human control. The internal side of the valve is connected to pipes. It is not simply just a hole through the hull, as a somewhat hysterical officer tried to infer at the hearings.

My question is very simple: was there ever a fault in the fail-safe mechanism, as has been alleged? The parliament is entitled to an answer to that question, and a clear answer of yes or no has never been given. We hear a lot of bluster from Navy about how stringent their submarine safety procedures are. If that is so, why the difficulty in giving a simple answer to a simple question? While on the subject of safety, can I put on the record another safety question, again not a statement of fact. I ask: was the sub safe system completely bypassed in 1997 when HMAS Collins went to sea and dived with the fore planes inoperable due to a hydraulic fault? Did the Deputy Chief of the Naval Staff have to order Collins to surface and return to harbour? Again the question requires a simple yes or no: did it happen? With only two hydroplanes on the fin and with both locked in the neutral position, if this did happen, it could only be described as a reckless and foolhardy action. Again, if it did occur, how did it get past the sub safe process?

I want to make it clear in public that I have no hesitation at all about being concerned for the lives of service personnel. I deplore very much the policy of Navy to attack anyone who raises safety issues on the grounds that it causes needless emotional distress to crews' families. I will not be silenced by such crude methods. Had those of us who knew the operational shortcomings of Army aviation prior to the Black Hawk tragedy been more vigorous in our criticism in public, perhaps that tragedy may never have occurred, and that is a matter that is on my conscience.

Finally, let me turn to another act of Defence that was quite unworthy of them. That is the assertion that we cannot have any leading edge technologies, and we cannot therefore have the best military equipment in the world, unless we take high risks, and risks mean that we have the situation we are in with the Collins program at the present time. It is quite wrong to use ambition as a cloak for inadequacies and inefficiencies in management. Yes, we do want the best technology, and we all recognise and accept that there are risks involved in going down that path. There is simply no way of making progress in human affairs without taking risks. What critics object to is that the Defence acquisitions department have no risk management strategy in place. In fact, they do not even recognise that they do not have a policy. When troubles come, they do not take the appropriate action at the time. They pretend it is not occurring and hope it all goes away. When it becomes public, as it always will, they move belatedly into damage control. We have potentially a good submarine in the Collins class submarine. The problems we have with it are real, and they demand real management skills to overcome them.

talk.start.para: âThis afternoon we were discussing a Privileges Committee report concerning complaints from a number of academics who had written to the Privileges Committee concerned about statements that had been made involving Greenwich University. These are the same academics who on Monday, 17 May, wrote to the Prime Minister about some of the remarks that I had made.
âHave you prepared an apology?

âTwo of them suggested that the matter be referred to the United States State Department in Washington so that the matter could be referred to at an intergovernmental level with the Australian government. Senator Tierney asks me if I have prepared an apology. I indicate to Senator Tierney that, given the investigation that is under way as a result of the concerns that have been expressed by me, by vice-chancellors and by state governments, and given the concerns expressed by the Minister for Tertiary Education and Training in the state of Victoriaâwho said on 6 May that he was very concerned about the lack of rigorous processes of review, compared with those carried out by the states, before recognition was given to Greenwich University by the parliament of Norfolk IslandâI would have thought that the only apology that is going to be prepared is one by the Prime Minister to the people of Australia concerning the incompetence and buffoonery of his ministers in allowing this disgraceful episode to go on for as long as it has.

speech.para: I indicated this afternoon that in America there is a view that a thousand flowers ought to bloom in higher education, but in my judgment we might not want some of these to take root in Australia, or we might never want to plant them here in the first place. I have expressed the concern that our university system guards its reputation jealously, for very good cause. It has a reputation built up on the basis of an intellectual tradition of academic rigour built on the well-established empirical, rational and historical intellectual frameworks of science, letters and the arts. While there are important differences between our universities, what holds them together is this common sense of quality assurance and this commitment to rigour.

What is established here is a tradition which generalises the reputation for quality, which reaches right across the Australian higher education system. I think this is why we have been so spectacularly successful in developing an education export industry worth over $3 billion a year. On a per capita basis it is probably much greater than that of the United States. Even though here in the antipodes we are latecomers to the international education arena, we nonetheless have streaked ahead as a result of this commitment to quality. What I am concerned about is that prospective students from overseas should know that an Australian degree will be recognised worldwideâthat a professional qualification from an Australian university will open doors wherever it is used. It will be held up everywhere that because it is an Australian university degree it is a matter of substance and quality.

I suggest that this has now changed, and this is the question that is brought into stark relief by the actions of the Norfolk Island legislature that were directed and approved by the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald. He has brought an intruder of doubtful provenance into our midst. This one act has the potential to bring down the entire edifice of Australian higher education in terms of its international reputation. It is unfortunate that Australia's lack of a robust standard of accreditation procedures has left us as what can be described as sitting ducks for the interlopers from cyberspace, for these so-called virtual universities. We simply do not have a regulatory framework to deal with this problem. The Internet has managed to elude the many safeguards that currently exist for the rest of the university system.

The ACCC has prosecuted the case of another charlatan institution in recent timesâthat is, the Australasian Institute, which is registered on the Caribbean island of Grenada. The institute has been found guilty of misleading and deceptive conduct. The court has ordered this institution to cease advertising its web based degree and to stop making false claims. It can no longer seek student enrolments.

Australia's laws leave us wide open under the present arrangements. Our company law and education regulation measures are woefully inadequate to deal with these contemporary problems. By means of the Trade Practices Act, the Federal Court can take retrospective action, but it cannot stop shonky outfits from setting up in the first place. The government is trying to repair the damage done by the establishment of Greenwich University itself. It is worth while asking how this entity managed to slip through the safety net so easily.

talk.start.para: âWhere's your proof?

âIt would seem that we have an answer. We heard in the last round of estimates just what that answer is. When speculating on matters such as this we can see that, as is so often the case in politics, this is another example of a stuff-up rather than a conspiracyâa stuff-up of monumental proportions. The territories department and its minister, Senator Ian Macdonald, were misled by unscrupulous operators who played on their ignorance about matters of higher educa tion in general and Internet universities in particular.

speech.para: Greenwich University apparently gave assurances to the Norfolk Island Administrator that it would operate only on Norfolk Island. Only a fool like the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government would accept such assurances.

talk.start.para: âOrder! I ask you to withdraw that reference to the minister.

âI will withdraw whatever you ask me to. At the same time, it has made no secret of the fact that it is a virtual institution to which the national and physical borders of the island and its coastline are absolutely irrelevant. It took our bureaucrats and our worthy ministers for complete mugs. That is how we have allowed an institution which has already been hounded out of America and New Zealand to set up as a duly legislated Australian university.

speech.para: We have been told that these matters were handled at the junior officer level within the department. How could such an important matter be dealt with at a junior officer level within the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs? When the department of territories wrote to the department of education and asked about the processes for the approval of an external studies university, one would presume that the minister would have thought that something was wrong when he got assurances that the university would operate only on Norfolk Island. However, none of these problems seemed to occur to this minister.

Australia is now being treated as a happy hunting ground for unscrupulous operators. Our legislative framework is crumbling under the encroachment. Island havens, offshore operations, sneaky company structures and so on are all part of their arsenal. Greenwich University has operated as a trojan horse to breach Fortress Australia. The rest of the mob of corporate spivs and Dodgy Brothers are all claiming to run universities and they have been allowed to enter through this process. Reputations are important, and apparently some of those involved in Greenwich University feel that their reputations have been besmirched. They have written to the Prime Minister about my concerns.

talk.start.para: âThey have, and they have written to the Privileges Committee about you.

âThey have threatened to create an international incident of the whole affair. I wish them well. There are reputations, and there are others who have reputations. Some unsuspecting academics, whose qualifications and credentials are beyond approach, have got themselves mixed up with this untrustworthy lot. I hope these persons, should they exist, can extract themselves from their embarrassment.
âYou're the one who should be embarrassed!

âThe details of these individuals have been provided to the Senate and are all on the web site, as is the prospectus of Greenwich University itself. These simple research tools are available to any senator and they ought to have been available to the departments within this government.

speech.para: Senator Tierney interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âWe have been able to establish accreditation by an Indian tribe. We have seen courses in do-it-yourself space travel and degrees from universities with names like New Utopia. Does that sound far fetched? This is the pattern which is emerging with regard to this university. I say to Senator Tierney and all those who wish to defend these sorts of shonky outfits: if you make your bed, you have got to lie in it.
âYou're the only shonky one, mate.

âI look forward to seeing Senator Tierney come in here and apologise when his own government's inquiry demonstrates that this university has not been able to measure up to the standards of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and to the time when his own minister has to acknowledge the incompetence of his colleague Senator Ian Macdonald. A lot more is at stake here than just reputations. The welfare of students is at stake. When you weigh up the issues, the sensitivities of a few individuals are of relatively minor significance in the general scheme of things.

speech.para: I expect to receive criticism, but I intend to pursue this question and I seek to clean up this mess. It is not about the small niceties of a few Americans who are claiming that the particular institutions in which they have worked are above reproach. We know about American universities: some of them are very good; others are nothing more than Weet Bix packet operations. The university on Norfolk Island is one of those X-Files operations. I think it is appropriate that it be identified as such.

talk.start.para: âI call Senator Bartlett.
âMadam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: Senator Bartlett is not on the list.
âSenator Bartlett is speaking in lieu of Senator Stott Despoja. I should have called Senator Bartlett prior to this, based on his explanation to me, so I am calling him now.

âI wish to put on the record the reasons why I was unable to support the package of taxation legislation which passed through this chamber earlier todayâwithout reflecting on the vote of the Senate, of courseâas I did not have the opportunity to do so during the debate on that package of bills. My opposition was not about whether or not I have a philosophical objection to a GST. I have always willingly supported the platform which the Democrats took to the last election and the position and recommendations that the party put forward in its Senate committee report on that package of bills.

speech.para: My basic concern is that the final legislation still risks making our tax system more regressive than it currently is, despite the significant improvements which have been made to it by the Australian Democrats. Changing the structure of our tax system so that it relies more heavily on indirect taxes makes it more difficult to ensure just outcomes. I recognise that some of my colleagues genuinely believe differently on this matter, and I note the very significant improvements in both fairness and environmental outcomes which have been negotiated by people within the parliamentary wing of the Australian Democrats.

This package passed regardless of my vote of course but I do take my responsibilities as an individual member of parliament and as a Democrat very seriously. I cannot vote for something that I am fundamentally opposed to and it is obviously up to the voters of Queensland and to Democrat members to pass judgment on my actions on this issue. I am appreciative of the repeated statements from my parliamentary colleagues and from the Democrat membership respecting and supporting my right to vote in accordance with my beliefs on this matter. I had certainly consulted widely with Democrat members and supporters, particularly in Queensland, prior to reaching this decision. I do urge all members of the Democrats to recognise that the party's core principles have not changed and to recognise that the Democrats still represent the strongest vehicle in Australian politics to achieve significant social, economic and environmental advancement.

Voting separately from my parliamentary leader is not something that I do lightly, nor something that I expect to do often. Despite the views expressed by some political commentators, I do not believe the taxation agreements should be seen as signalling an ideological shift by the Australian Democrats. Every change that the Democrats forced to the original tax package was driven by concern for greater social equity or environmental protection. This demonstrates very clearly that the Democrats have used and will continue to use our balance of power role to pursue the party's core aims as strongly as ever.

As a Queenslander I had some specific concerns about the employment impacts of the GST, especially on the tourism industry, a major employer in my own state. I was also concerned about the potential loss of extra revenue in the clearly identified revenue stream which would have been provided to local government in Queensland. I recognise and understand the concerns that many people have about the large increase which will be provided in subsidies for fossil fuel usage. However, I would urge environmentalists to examine the package as a whole and to consider just how significant some of the changes which the Democrats have forced will be. The significance of the long-term improvements which the Democrats have gained in the environmental area should not be underestimated, and I urge all people to look at the detailed analysis that has been provided by all different sources.

The Democrats have forced the coalition government to take environmental concerns seriously and have made environmental issues a central component of the national political agenda for the first time in many years. This is a significant achievement, one which, as the party's environment spokesperson, I look forward to building on in coming months. Any governmentâand indeed any partyâwhich takes environmental issues seriously and seeks to achieve constructive and positive moves forward is more likely to receive the Democrats' support.

I have already expressed my concern about the potential impact of the GST on non-profit organisations. As I am sure all senators would acknowledge, the non-profit sector plays an invaluable role in the community both socially and economically and it is already considerably underresourced. I know work is ongoing to minimise and eliminate the potential threat to that sector. I know all of my party colleagues will be focused on ensuring that outcome and I will certainly be working along with them to achieve that goal. I have also expressed concerns in this chamber about the potential impact of the tax changes on housing costs, an area I have had some involvement in over many years and again one that I will certainly continue to monitor.

I have spent most of the last nine or more years of my life holding a variety of senior positions within the Democrats, encouraging the party to be more pragmatic. I have never been someone who believes the party should only support initiatives that represent 100 per cent of party policies and should refuse to support anything that does not go the whole way. I am happy to support anything that moves, in even a small way overall, towards achieving Democrat policy and principles. I urge all those who do have concerns with what the Democrat parliamentary party has negotiated with the government to recognise that those in the party who are able to support the package do so because of a genuine belief that it is best for Australia and it meets the basic aims and direction of Democrat policy and principles.

In my first speech to the Senate, I spoke at length about the central and crucial role which the members of the Australian Democrats play in sustaining and building the party and the broader social movement which it represents. Perhaps more than any other party the Democrats rely on member input and involvement and celebrate that. As I said in that first speech, few us from any party in this chamber and certainly none of us in the Democrats would be here in parliament without the `selfless dedication and commitment of countless people who contribute so much of their own time, money and energy simply because they believe in the ideals and policies of the party'.

It is no secret that some members of the Democrats are unhappy with the taxation legislation. People holding different views is not unusual in any sizeable organisation and the Democrats have always recognised and promoted the importance of diversity. I make a special plea to those members who are concerned to recognise this fact and to stay with the party. Our core principles remain and only by those members' continued involvement will we be able to ensure that the goals, objectives and principles of the party are retained. As I said in this chamber last week, if one were to follow the rationale of Senator Bob Brown and resign from a party every time one disagreed with a decision, one would soon end upâlike himâin a party of one.

The Democrats have always believed in accommodating and encouraging a diversity of views within the framework of our overall principles. Those core principles have not changed and we need all our members to stay on board and to increase their involvement to ensure that they do not change. The party is now moving into a position of greater power and we need even more involvement and support from our members to ensure we exercise that power responsibly and effectively. Now is the time for even greater member input to take advantage of the extra power and responsibilities which the Democrats hold. I call on all members not to drop out but to pitch in even further.

In the brief amount of time left, I would like to mention brieflyâand pay tribute toâa Queensland member, a typical example of the people I mentioned previously who gave so much of their own time and energy because they believed in the partyâa person called Steve Hunter, who tragically died a week ago. Steve was the Secretary of the Democrats' Logan Branch, just south of Brisbane, for a number of years. Steve put a great deal of effort into keeping that branch going through a low ebb in that branch's history, certainly ensuring that the branch was able to go on to stronger things since. I pass on my commiserations to his family and I say thank you to Steve for all he contributed to the party.

I would also like to wish well all those senators who are retiring from this place in a couple of days time. Although I have not had a great deal to do with Senator Sandy Macdonald and Senator Synon, I certainly wish them well. Four senators from Queensland are moving onâa significant proportion of my state's representation will be changing over in a few days time. Senator MacGibbon, who spoke before, is well recognised for his contribution over many years in the areas of defence and foreign affairs in particular. Senator Reynolds is widely respected amongst many Democrat supporters for her strong stance on, particularly, indigenous issues, environment issues and women's issues, among others. I wish Senator Colston well. He is certainly someone who contributed a lot in the area of procedure within the Senate and in some of those less well-known committees such as the Regulations and Ordinances Committee which still play an important role. Senator O'Chee is someone whom I have also had experience with in the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and I got a clearer insight into the importance of that committee. Whilst I do not necessarily agree with a lot he says, I certainly feel that the way he says things is a helluva lot better than I will ever manage. He is one of the better public speakers I have seen. Finally, farewell to Senator Margetts. These days it is probably not as great a comfort to a Green party person to get a tribute from the Democrats as it might have been a few weeks ago, but I do acknowledge the very considerable contribution she has made. I have great respect for the quality and the integrity of her work, and she is certainly an example I will look to into the future. I wish her well in her future endeavours.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight with the second speech relating to Greenwich University. It is a great pity that in this Senate we have now reached a very low point in its history in terms of the denigration of people and institutions that have very little chance to redress this on the public record. I speak particularly of Senator Carr's criticisms of the institution of Greenwich University, its staff and its courses. Through four speeches in this chamber plus on one occasionâ
âSix, and five questions.

âSix speeches, five questions and four hours in one estimates committee. Senator Carr, you have chalked up and wasted the time of this chamber on a totally useless pursuit in which you have denigrated people's good names. You have put on the public record the besmirching of an institution which does have, as I will prove yet again tonight, on a second occasion, quite a good reputation overseas with the students who are graduatesâto whom I will refer to in a minuteâwith associated staff of the university, and with those who have been subject to the work of that university.

speech.para: Tonight I want to focus in particular on Senator Carr's comments on curriculum. His speech more recently related to the staff, and I did respond to that. The staff have written to me, greatly dismayed that their names have been dragged through the mud in this place and have been besmirched. That is causing them great trauma and problems in their own lives, and they have written to me about that. I also commend them for taking matters into their own hands by writing to the Privileges Committee of this Senate and have referred Senator Carr to the Privileges Committee. The Privileges Committee today directed that the letters which these people have used to defend their own reputations be incorporated in the Hansard record, something which I did try to do during the last speech but was denied by Senator Carr. I was going to try to incorporate them tonight, but that has already been done by the Privileges Committee, and I thank the committee for that.

Tonight I want to focus on the curriculum of Greenwich, something that Senator Carr, through his various questions speeches and comments in estimates, has chosen to denigrate. Senator Carr, what do you think of these courses, and do you think they have an appropriate place in a university: comparative approaches to mysticism, history of tourism and travel, Confuscian politics in a rocky mountain world, sex and scandal, post-colonialism, gender and sexuality, andâone that is right up your alley, Senator Carrâsocialist law?

I ask Senator Carr: in the proper role of universities, are these proper academic studies? I wonder what your response is. Is this the curriculum of Greenwich University I am reading out? No. What I am reading from is the curriculum of the University of Sydneyâa university with a top reputation in this country. I am not denigrating the University of Sydney; I am trying to prove to you that you cannot judge the academic rigour of a course by its title. That is exactly what Senator Carr has sought to do on a number of occasions in this Senateâhe has taken the title and poked fun at it. The reason is that he does not understand the leading edges of knowledge, particularly the leading edges of interdisciplinary knowledge, in modern academic study.

Rather than my making a statement here in judgment of the programs of the university, I think we should hear from the people involved. From Ian Mackechnie, we have this comment on the debate in the Senate on Greenwich University:
Congratulations to Senator Tierney for his outspoken response to Senator Carr's continuous lies and falsehoods peddled under the privilege of parliament.

As both a graduate of Greenwich and one who has been closely attached to the university, its staff and its faculty over many years, I can assure Senator Tierney, Carr, Kemp, the Prime Minister and anyone else who is willing to listen to the facts that Greenwich has a reputation, credibility and standards that would exceed most Australian universities. And I can say that through personal experience, having studied through several Australian universities.
A comment from a student:
As a September 1998 Ph.D. graduate of Greenwich, I am compelled to offer the following as it relates to my educational experience as a Greenwich student:
First, I am a retired U.S. Navy Captain and, for the last 8 years have been involved in the education of adult learners . . .
He says that he has degrees from three universities in the United States and enrolled in the PhD course at Greenwich University. He continues:

. . . I did a considerable amount of research before deciding to enrol in a non-traditional degree awarding institution. Since my workday is routinely a 10-12 hour one, with a considerable amount of travel required, coupled with the fact that . . . I had 3 children at home under the age of 16, it was impractical for me to pursue a Ph.D. in a traditional institution. My research involved review of Greenwich's program by several respected educators. Each of these individuals stated that short of a residency requirement, the university met the standard for most doctoral degree requirements. In addition to the favourable comments of these individuals, the credentials of Greenwich University adjunct faculty particularly impressed me.

All three courses in my dissertation were completed in my own time in 18 months. The writing of my dissertation took an additional 27 months. Two additional readers reviewed my dissertation and, although not then a course requirement, I conducted an oral defence of my dissertation with Dr MacDonald.

In summary, my Greenwich University experience was academically challenging and intellectually rewarding. Through its flexible self-paced program, I can say without reservation it was academically more rigorous than the programs I experienced at the Naval War College, Regina University and Old Dominion University.

Finally, I would like to turn to comments that I think sum up Senator Carr's appalling ignorance of the academic world and how you judge standards. I will allow his words to deliver the coup de grace on this matter. This is from Dr Claudine Jeanrenaud. He is well-read in the field of depth psychology. Do you know what that is, Senator Carr? I doubt it. Senator Carr has advertised his ignorance of this field of psychology. That psychology is based on the work of Carl Jung. Do you know who Carl Jung is, Senator Carr? He is the famous Swiss psychologist, second only in the world to Freud. He writes on 5 April:

Next time he, Senator Carr, plans to endeavour in the smashing of an entire body of academic studies, he better do his homework first, for surely he didn't intend to demonstrate his ignorance to the whole world.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to speak on the issue of racial discrimination. All senators in this place are aware of racial discrimination. We have read about it in the newspapers or have heard about some form of discrimination based on the colour of a person's skin, the language they speak or their country of origin. But how many of us have ever experienced it first-hand? How many of us have ever personally known somebody who has been a victim of racism? I am sure most senators have. I would like to share with the Senate tonight an experience I had recently which upset me greatly.

speech.para: A friend of mine who, by the way, has white skinânot that it matters at all; of course, it should never matterâand speaks English as her first language became aware that the differential treatment she had received for the past few years in her workplace was actually racially driven. It was based purely on her country of origin and the way she spoke. Throughout the years of her employment, she always gave 150 per cent effort in whatever she did, because that is the kind of person she is, but she was very rarely ever given the recognition her work deserved.

She was always denied access to any pay rises, even though she knew that many of her colleagues had received pay increases on a regular basis. When she finally asked for a pay increase, she was told, `You were not worth what you were getting when you started, but you are now; so forget it.' Even with four years experience behind her, she was still getting the same rate of pay as a new starter and, even two years further down the track, she remained on that same level. Even though this was always a puzzle to her, she got on with the job because she loved what she did so passionately. Ironically, she worked in a job that was for the benefit of others.

The simple fact of the matter was that the person at the top of the organisation had a problem with her accent and the confidence that women from her country of origin portrayed. Recently all was revealed by one of her colleagues at her farewell function, where she was told that the problem between her and the boss had always been that he could never get over the way she spoke and that he regarded the women from her country of origin to be all the sameâto his way of thinking, aggressive and forceful. This simple statement cut right to the core of her very soul, as the truth of the matter began to sink in. Looking back over the years at the barriers and obstacles she had had to deal with on a constant basis with this job, the true realisation that she had been the victim of racial discrimination was almost too much to bear.

Then the final blow came when she confided in another of her colleagues as to what had been said and discovered that it was common knowledge amongst the workplace but that no-one would dare say anything to her because they did not want to hurt her feelings. For many years she had been the brunt of jokes from many of her coworkers about the way she pronounced certain words, but had just laughed along with everyone else in the hope that, if she did not react, it would soon stop, all the while secretly wishing they would stop and had even attempted to alter the way she spoke. But even through all of this, she never suspected that this could be racially driven or that her so-called friends and coworkers could be aware of what was happening and actively partake in such demeaning behaviour.

As we sat there having a quiet drink she told me what had happened. I could visibly see the pain it caused her, as the tears began to well in her eyesâit had all become too real. I was horrified to think that someone I knew had been the victim of such disgusting behaviour. She was being discriminated against not only on the basis of how she spoke but also because she happened to come from a country where the women are taught to be confident in their own abilities.

It brings to light the ugly realisation of how deeply entrenched racial discrimination has become with regard to some people's behaviour in today's society. I think the worst part of all this is that these people are all good people and probably do not even realise what they have done. I am quite sure that, if you asked many of them, they would claim they were not racist. We pride ourselves in this country on the fact that we live in a multicultural society, and we like to think that we are civilised and tolerant of all newcomers to Australia, who come here because they want a better way of life. Indeed, I myself am a migrant, as most senators would know, and I believe that I have had a better life and far more opportunities in Australia than I would have had in the country of my birth. I very much doubt that, if I had stayed in the country of my birth, I would today have been in the House of Lords. I am damn sure I would not be.

This is a disturbing story. I do not believe the majority of Australians are racist or intolerant, even with the rise of the One Nation Party, which I believe did attract as their followers many of the rednecks in our society. Let's face it, in all societies there is this redneck element. I would hope that this is an isolated incident. If we encounter this sort of disgraceful behaviour I think it is up to all of us, in any job or from any walk of life, to point out to the perpetrator the hurt he or she is causing because of his or her personal bias. Probably this sort of person should not have been in a position of authority. Surely an employee should be judged on the merit of their work, not on their accent.

Senators, I ask you to consider this: if a person who looks the same and speaks the same language as any average Australian can become a victim of racism, what must it be like for a person who has a different skin colour or differently shaped eyes or who has difficulty with the English language? What must that person have to put up with? What my friend encountered was discrimination not only towards her nationality but also against her gender. There is no place for this in a civilised society. Thank goodness it is not widespread, otherwise many of us in this chamber today would not be in the positions of employment that we currently enjoy.

talk.start.para: âI rarely speak during the adjournment debate; I think it is almost three years since I have done so. I come to this adjournment tonight only because I think there are a couple of important things that need to be said, particularly in relation to the fact that a number of the government's reform agenda items have been pushed past 30 June because of the intensity of the legislation presented to the parliament in this first session.

speech.para: I want to talk particularly about superannuation and the choice of funds in superannuation. Superannuation fund choice is an important public reform agenda item. Contrary to the views of some parties that would wish the issue to go away, it is still on the agenda. It is important that those who make legislation in Australia not be distracted by those who are in the business of protecting their own patch. It is always more instructive in these matters to look to what dispassionate players have to say about issues.

Let us take, for example, the Wallis inquiry into our financial system. Wallis was given the task of reporting on how our financial system could be better regulated and more able to achieve economies and cost savings. It reported that the cost to the users of the financial services industry is about $41 billion, or a little under 10 per cent of GDP. They presented to the government a package of reforms that will ultimately have the impact of driving down the cost of savings and investment in Australia. Wallis has made far-reaching recommendations, many of which have already been the subject of legislation that has passed through this Senate.

Superannuation fund choice was one of the areas pursued by Wallis. The inquiry found that, in relation to superannuation consumers, over half were in funds where members were unlikely to have been offered full choice. In fact, Wallis was advised by the then ISC that about 24 per cent of fund members have no choice of fund at all. This position is surely at odds with other services and goods that are chosen every day by consumersâfor example, banking and home loans. Individuals can go to a bank, a building society, a credit union or a mortgage originator and choose a service that suits their needs. The choice of home mortgage funds is one of the reasons behind the dramatic reductions in housing interest rates.

If a mortgage provider is charging interest rates that are above the market rates, the consumer can switch to another mortgage provider. In superannuation the position for the consumer is dramatically different. If, for example, the superannuation consumer is experiencing rates of return that are poor under the current regime, they like it or lump it. There are certain players in the superannuation industry who continue to mouth paternalistically that consumers are not ready to choose where their retirement savings should be directed. Is it that they want to continue their monopolistic control of the complexities of superannuation? Or is it that they are just protecting existing commercial interests?

If their logic were consistent, they would be saying that individuals on the receiving end of employment benefits amounting to hundreds of thousands of dollars should be denied the right to choose an annuity or a rollover vehicle. Could you imagine the outcry if this were government policy? The opponents of choice have not taken and do not take this stand, because the prudential and disclosure controls that we have are sound and have not given rise to market failure. These controls are almost identical to those which would be applicable if fund choice were to proceed. So it is rather refreshing to read and take note of the more independent observers and what they might have to say about choice. In its 88th recommendation the Wallis inquiry said:

Employees should be provided with choice of fund, subject to any constraints about administrative costs and fund liquidity. Where superannuation benefits vest in a member, that member should have the right to transfer the amounts to any complying fund. Where a member chooses to exercise that right, payments should be transferred to the chosen fund as soon as practicable, subject to controls necessary to maintain orderly management for the benefit of all fund members.
Transfer costs, including those incurred as a result of regulatory requirements, should be transparent and reasonable.

However, Wallis is now two years old, and we still do not have any semblance of choice in our superannuation fund arrangements. As I said at the beginning, the opponents of choice would no doubt want the issue to die, but it will not if the consumer movement has its way.

Could I advise the Senate that earlier this month the Consumer Policy Research Centre released its `Keys to Superannuation Choice' discussion paper. What did it say about fund choice and whether superannuation should continue to be paternalistically dispensed or whether there should be mandatory investment choice prior to moving down a fund choice route, and what proactive mechanisms would be needed if the choice route were followed? Time does not permit me to go into the report in detail, but I will advise that this group of consumers sends a clear and unequivocal message, and that is this: the centre supports the concept of superannuation fund choice. It has said at page 50 of its document:

The Centre believes that the development of a legislative regime for superannuation choice must proceed in a staged manner subject to the resolution of the major issues affecting its introduction such as education, disclosure, consumer protection, alternative dispute resolution mechanisms and life insurance. However, the Centre also believes that these tasks must be undertaken quickly, as superannuation choice is already beginning to take place in the market.

Interestingly, the centre has been reported as saying that the argument about investment choice and fund choice is irrelevant. It says that we should have both, and soon. We on the government side of the chamber look forward to working with consumers and others in achieving an optimal choice outcome. We hope that senators sitting on the non-government benches will move soon to review their positions and not leave themselves open to a charge that they are ignoring the needs and wishes of consumers.

There have been a number of letters to the papers in recent times, letters which go to the heart of the choice of super funds, and in fact there was one letter which I would like to table, if the Manager of Opposition Business will allow me, after I have shown it to himâif I could get his attention, which I cannot. This letter talks about the choice of super fund benefits to consumers and comments about a letter about superannuation choice which is misguided, and about a choice of fund regime that is linked to a consumer package, such as the Corporate Law Economic Reform Program, having the potential to greatly enhance consumer rights. I would like to table the details of that letter.

I can only stress to the Senate that in fact the issue of choice of super fund is one that will be dealt with in, hopefully, the latter part of the year. It is of interest to consumers. As I said earlier in my speech, we have a situation where people are allowed to choose whether they go to a bank or a building society or any number of other organisations to get a house loan or to fund something else in that regard but where, when it comes to the choice of super funds, a vast number of people in Australia who are in superannuation funds have no choice and no right to choose any fund of their own for their investment. I hope that the Senate will see the sense of the recommendations of the Wallis inquiry and that the issue of superannuation fund choice is one that will be dealt with positively before the end of the year.

talk.start.para: âAre you seeking leave to table that document?
âI seek leave to table the document.
âThere being no objection, and it being agree able to the Democrats' Acting Deputy Whip as well, leave is granted.

âTonight Four Corners on the ABC ran a program on the Australian Democrats. One of the areas they chose to highlight was the so-called tensions within the party. Due to speculation in the media and a potential leadership petition, I wish to put on record my position. This leadership spill is not about whether I challenge or become leader, nor about my position as deputy. It is not about my behaviour or my perspective on the GSTâalthough, of course, I recognise that the leadership spill was interpreted by the national president, as is his right, to include my position as deputy.

speech.para: Nevertheless, in relation to speculation about a leadership challenge, I adhere to my recent statements. Two weeks ago, I said I would not challenge our leader, Senator Meg Lees, and I am sticking to that positionâeven allowing for extraordinary events, such as those that have occurred in the past week and, of course, for a degree of pressure and support. My reasons for not standing include the fact that I meant what I said two weeks agoâthose reasons remain the sameâand also because I do not wish current tensions within the party to be exacerbated further.

I also recognise that minimising tension is a two-way street. It means that the members have to respect the rights and decisions of the members of parliament, the senators; but, on the other hand, we also have to respect the will and the decisions of our members. That is a fundamental philosophy and value to which the Democrats adhere. I also recognise that we cannot afford as legislators, as members of our party room, to dismiss the concerns or the dissent among our membersâor, indeed, to dismiss any suggestion that there is discomfort among the membership. My decision to not stand for the leadership is not about my not being ready or about a lack of support. It is because it is inappropriate, and I think it may lead to further party unrest.

What is true is that I differ from my party in relation to its decision on the GST package. Today, indeed, I exercised my right as a Democrat senator, a right that is part of our constitution, to exercise my vote according to conscience, as you did, Mr Acting Deputy President Bartlett. I will continue to work hard as Deputy Leader of this party, with a solid commitment to its principlesâprinciples of accountability, democracy, social justice and ecological sustainability. I will also encourage our members to work for the good of the party, to work together in order to bring about the progressive policies that we stand for. I do not dismiss the concerns that have been aired, the frustrations to which attention has been drawn.

I echo the sentiments tonight of my colleague Senator Bartlett in relation to his plea to the membership. I know that some of our membersâperhaps many of our membersâwill be disappointed by today's vote on the GST, but the answer is not to leave the party or to spill the leadership positions; it is to work hard, to commit ourselves to the party, the processes and the policy work, and to influence the party by remaining involved, by participating in the process. As Senator Bartlett has said on record tonight, the decision today does not have to represent an ideological shift in our party. All senators, all the party room, remain committed to and united in our pursuit of social justice, ecological sustainability and democracy.

Of course, there has always been debate and discussion in our party about the role of the party and the parliamentary wings of the Australian Democrats. Tonight's Four Corners program did highlight the fact that some of our members are frustrated on this occasion by the actions of the parliamentary wing and they have chosen to exercise their right to complain through one of the mechanisms available to them, which is a ballot on the tax agreement. My message tonight is for our members: you determine our policy and you ensure that the party room is guided by the party's principles. I believe we are a true grassroots party, a participatory and democratic party. These are values we all cherish. We will listen to our members and act on their concerns, but they must stay involved. This is what makes the Australian Democrats different

I have watched tonightâindeed, over the last couple of weeksâwith amazement as the media have grappled with this notion of direct participation and with the notion of a conscience vote. Clearly, many observers have a lot to learn about how the Democrats work, what sets us apart from the old parties. Hopefully, the media, other commentators and the legislators will learn quickly about the ways of our party, a party that has always prized conscience and direct participation in processes and policy.

As you well know, Mr Acting Deputy President, it is not easy to vote differently from your colleagues. So I thank the many branches, members and divisions that have sent messages or motions of support. I also acknowledge the positive comments for the work that my leader, Senator Meg Lees, has done in negotiating improvements to the package. I hope that this process is not going to destabilise our party, but that we will emerge from this healthy debate stronger and as always the real alternative to the old parties in this place.

talk.start.para: âThat sounded more like a policy speech to me than anything else. It is interesting just to reflect that the party that tries to say that the other parties are old parties is in fact now 22 years old. So it has been around for a couple of decades. I think the term `old parties' is now being used because the Democrats cannot bring themselves to say `major parties'âlike the major parties that have major support.

speech.para: The purpose of my rising tonight was to invite Senator Carr to consider the way that Senator Gibbs conducted herself tonight in the adjournment debate. I have to say to you that Senator Gibbs's speech was very good. I think it did credit to her and to the Senate. That is in stark contradistinction to Senator Carr's contribution, which is a continuation of his unprincipled and unsustained attack on Greenwich University.

Over the months now, we have had to listen in this place to these unprincipled and unsustained attacks. Senator Tierney, to his great credit, has done a welter of research on this and has completely exposed Senator Carr's lack of intellectual integrity and indeed the bankruptness of his arguments in relation to the allegations he has been making against Greenwich University. Indeed, one of the things that Senator Carr has been accusing Greenwich University of in recent times is that they had people of no real academic repute. I think that has been absolutely and utterly laid to rest. A Privileges Committeeâdominated, as I understand it, by the Labor Party and chaired by Labor senator Robert Rayâhas agreed that certain statements, for want of a better term, of self-defence by people from Greenwich University ought to be incorporated into Hansard. These are statements, as I understand it, thatâ

talk.start.para: âExpose them for what they are.

âI suggest that, after the adjournment debate, Senator Carr ought to take himself to Labor senator Ray's rooms and just ask him why it was that Senator Ray and the Labor Party members on the Privileges Committee considered themselves constrained to suggest in their report that the statements from seven people from Greenwich University be incorporated in Hansard to set the record straight in relation to the heinous allegations made by Senator Carr.
âThat is just drivel, and you know it. It is their right of reply, that is all.

âIt is their right of reply, Senator Carr, and I am very pleased that that is now on the record, because the Privileges Committee, as I understand the rules, only considers that a right of reply ought to be given in very special circumstances. It would not give it to just anybody.
âNonsense! What a complete lot of nonsense.

âMr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I did not think it was possible for a senator to make two adjournment contributions in the one evening. Failing that, it is quite clearly disorderly for Senator Carr to continue carrying on in the way he is doing. I beg you, Mr Acting Deputy President, so that we can conduct the debate in some decorum, to ask him to come to order.
âI ask Senator Carr to cease interjecting.

âI think those few people who would still be listening at this late hour and those who might read the Hansard would not be aware of the volume of Senator Carr's interjections. It has been one of those tactics that we have become used to with Senator Carr. When there is a deficit in his reasoning, he becomes a lot more voluminous to try to make a point. He becomes a lot more repetitious in the hope that that deficit of reasoning will somehow be overcome by volume and repetition. The senator ought to take the tip that it will not work. Senator Tierney, through very reasoned debate and considered contributions to this chamber, has now exposed Senator Carr's contribution as being intellectually lacking in rigourâand in fact some people would say `bankrupt'. Other words spring to mind which may well be unparliamentary, so I will not use them.

speech.para: In relation to the allegation of mickey mouse courses being available at Greenwich University, it seems very strange for a leading figure of the socialist left to make such allegations. I remember that about 20 years ago when I was at university, even at my home university, the intellectually bankrupt of the Left would run courses on campus that some of us would describe as mickey mouse courses. Senator Tierney has assisted us in reading out a list of courses that are, or were, available at Sydney University. Confucian politics in a rocky modern world may well take the cakeâor indeed comparative approaches to mysticism, or Senator Carr's favourite socialist law. I think there are only one or two regimes left in the world that would describe themselves as socialist and that would be Cuba and North Korea. That is the modernity, I suppose, that Senator Carr brings to intellectual rigour.

talk.start.para: âYou believe Malcolm Fraser was a socialist, don't you? Do you still hold that view about Malcolm Fraser?

âI do not know what you are alleging that I have ever said about Malcolm Fraser, other than that I think he was a great Prime Minister. I do happen to know what a former Labor premier said about Senator Carr. He did not say it only once; he said it many a time. Senator Carr take the tip: it was not too flattering. When the Labor Party was in government, it gave postgraduate grants of over $25,000 to two peopleâone to do a thesis on tourism in fascist Italy and another to do medieval witchcraft. That is the basis on which the Australian Labor Party, through Senator Carr, comes to this debate. I note that that gem that was contributed to this debate was provided to me by one Senator Bill O'Chee, whom we will sorely miss.
âIt will be his last effort.

âIt may well be his last effort, but let me simply say to the Senate and therefore to Senator Carr, because unfortunately he is part of the Senate, that Senator O'Chee's contributions during his period in the Senate will always outdo Senator Carr's contribution no matter how many decades Senator Carr remains in this place.

speech.para: It is with a tinge of sadness that I again note Senator O'Chee's departure from this place as of 30 June. I suppose that is the great contradistinction between Senator O'Chee and Senator Carr, in as much as Senator O'Chee has been a man of principle. We on this side would argue that he was the victim of One Nation in his own state of Queensland. However, he took a very principled stance against One Nation, for which I happen to take my hat off to him. If Senator Carr was not so busy not thinking and had listened to the contribution by Senator Gibbs, he would feel, like so many other senators, that Senator O'Chee's departure from this place is a matter to be greatly regretted.

In this game of politics, from time to time very genuine individuals make allegations or assertions that, on further reflection or further analysis, cannot be sustained. Then the onus is on those senators to come into this place and correct the record. Unfortunately, what we have seen from the Labor Party time and again are unsubstantiated allegations. When they have been exposed as being completely without foundation, like the allegations against the Baillieu family when certain people supposedly involved in this intrigue had been dead for 30 and 50 years and were unable to have performed this activityâunless, of course, you believe in the Labor Party's view of medieval witchcraftâthe Labor Party should have apologised, but they never did. The challenge to Senator Carr is to apologise. (Time expired)
